DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P:
TO publish a Work with the Title borne by this, may, per∣haps, by some, be thought presump∣tion, when it is recollected that Madame de Genlis has already oc∣cupied the Dramatic line, in a man∣ner to be imitated by few, and, probably, to be equalled by none.—But a comparison of this work with the Theatre of Education, of that great Author, would be un∣fair as to execution, and unjust as to design.—The Writer of this Work does not, like Madame de Genlis, intend her Dramatic Dia∣logues to be performed; well a∣ware that the length of the Scenes, in some places, and the simplicity of the Plot in all, would render them lat and heavy in representa∣tion. The motives by which she was induced to throw her Stories
into Dialogue, were a belief that young people are easily captivated and interested by this manner of writing, and the convenience of a∣voiding the "said ," and "re∣plied she," which becomes so fa∣tiguing in a narration of any length, and which she was so often obli∣ged to break in her last work.
This short explanation the Au∣thoress thought due to herself, lest she should be suspected of endeav∣ouring to imitate one of the first Authors the Age has produces.

If these simple Dialogues should be considered as an additional bar∣rier against the encroachments of Error, and an additional support to the efforts of Virtue, the Writer will be most happy; and she trusts them, tho' not without fear, yet not without hope, to the candour of a generous Public, who at least will give her credit for purity of

Q.L: Our Passions gone, and Reason in her Throne,
We wonder at the Mischief we have done.

DIV2.HEAD: THE Misfortunes of Anger.
DIV2.STAGE: Mary enters, lifts up a tambour frame which appears to have been thrown down, picks up the span∣gles, silks, &c.—She speaks.
DIV2.P:
SO Miss Juliet has been here, I see!—What put her into a age with her tambour, I —Oh! I see, this rose-bud d look well, so down it we, warrant it, and here span∣gles and twist thrown . For my pat,
frame was not all broke to smash, it would have been like her.—Ah! here comes Miss Paulina! There's a young lady, marry, I wish our's was like her, but no hope of that!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Mary have you seen my cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: No, Miss, not since breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I left her here at her tambour frame—She said she would work while I read to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Aye, Miss, but some∣thing has gone wrong since that.—Here I found the frame, and there lay the siks—Truly, I'm glad I was not here, they'd have been thrown at my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Perhaps she is gone to her own room, I'll seek her; if she comes here in the mean time, Mary tell her I am up stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, Miss, to be sure I will.—(Paulina goes out.)—Ah! by my truth, there's some pleasure in doing any thing for you, one does not get pinched and called names!—So here's the Governess, yawning as usual, but just up.

DIV2.STAGE: (She speaks in a slow, dull manner, and yawns often.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well, Mary!—Where's Miss Juliet?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I don't know, Ma'am, not I, she is in one of her passions to-day; every thing goes wrong with her; she was ready to fight with the looking-glass, while I dressed her this morning, and I don't know how many pinches I got for not being quick enough to please her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P:
She's a strange
girl, I can't help laughing at her sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: 'Tis no laugh∣ing matter, ma'am, I can tell you that, and it only makes her worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: She fatigues me so! I really cannot stay with her long at a time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary,
SP.P: No, truly, you take care not to have too much trouble!
SP.STAGE: Mrs. Selwyn draws a chair indo∣lently, and takes out her work.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well, Mary, go and tell her to come to me, I want her to read.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am I'm quite afraid to go, she won't mind me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn,
SP.P: And she'll fatigue me sadly too, well, never mind, she'll come bye-and-bye.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: What's the matter with you, Fanny, what are you crying for?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Miss Juliet!—Miss Juliet!—Oh dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Child, don't make so much noise, what has Miss Juliet done to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Why, ma'am, an please you, she met me in the garden, a∣bout half an hour agone, I was a coming up, ma'am, to beg a little milk for my little sister, for mo∣ther is very bad, and so she said as how—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Don't talk so fast, let's hear what Miss Juliet did.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, and so ma'am, if you please, I met Miss Juliet; and so she asked me what I wanted, and so I told, and so she.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Grant me pa∣tience! How many more so's?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Don't make such a long story, Fanny, tell us, at once, what made you cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, I'm a going, so miss asked me to play wi' she, for she said his honour was gone out and Madam Selwyn wa'nt up, and Master Charles was gone to school, and Miss Paulina was up stairs, and she did not know what to do wi' herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: So, there's all the family disposed of.—Well, child, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Then we vent up stairs ma'am, and miss shewed me her doll, and we played, but at last,—Oh dear, oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: I never heard such a girl in my life.—What happened then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Why, miss beat me, yes, she did, ever so hard, and scratch'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: What all at once, without any cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, 'cause I let the doll fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn,
SP.P: What nonsense!—Go away, child, take your milk, and bid he cook give you some broth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fanny.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, thank you ma'am. (Aside.)—But I wo'nt come here any more to be beat a∣bout so. (Mary and Fanny go out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Where's Fanny Wood?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Gone home, miss, do you think any body will stay where you are, to be beat and scratched?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
I don't care. What
business had she to throw down my doll?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Do you think she did it on purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I don't know.—Let her take more care then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Has she spoil'd it?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well then, what was there to be in such a rage a∣bout?—Come and read.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Not till I have dressed my doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Well,—make haste then—(A pause, Mrs. Selwyn works but slowly and idly, Juliet dresses her doll, at last, she stamps her fot, and says:—
You tiresome creature, won't you be dress'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: My stars, Miss Juliet, how you make one start.—What is the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Why, my nasty doll is such a torment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Very pretty, to quarrel with a bit of painted wood!—Oh! you silly child!—Come, leave your doll, and let me hear you read.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I tell you I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Oh! you are a sweet little girl, so mild and so ob∣liging; how every body loves you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet,
SP.P: Let me alone then!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Pretty creature!—What a sweet face!—Look how your doll stares at you!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.STAGE: (Rising in a passion, and throwing her doll across the room.)
SP.P: I wish the doll was a thousand miles off, a little provoking crea∣ture!—(Mrs. Selwyn laughs.)—I won't be laugh'd at that I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P:
How will you
help it?—Leave off crying direct∣ly, or I will shut you up for two hours.—(Another pause, Juliet still cries, but by degrees becomes quiet, af∣ter some time she calls.)—Mary!—Mary

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: What now, miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I want Mary.—(calls)—Mary, I say!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Mercy, miss I came as soon as ever I heard you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: You are always so slow.—Take down my goldfinch, and fetch me some seed and water.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes miss. (She reaches the bird down, then goes out, and returns with some water and seed.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Come my pretty, let your mistress feed you, I love you very much—(She feeds it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Yes, you love it vastly just now, but sometimes you are ready to wring its neck, when it does not eat to please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: One would think Mrs. Selwyn liked to see her in a passion, she delights so in teaz∣ing her!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh, you little torment you won't eat out of my hand!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: There, I told you so, now, miss, you had better beat the bird, or throw it across the room, as you did your doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: So I will, if I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Do, I would ad∣vise you!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, how can you?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
Come, eat then.—You won't!—You nasty, little obsti∣nate, ungrateful creature,—I'll
teach you to teaze me, I will.—(She snatches the bird out of the cage in a passion, gives it a squeeze, then looks at it, and bursts into tears.)—Oh! Heaven, I have killed my bird!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh, dear, miss, I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Look at it, Mary, pray try if you can fetch it to life!—Oh my poor bird.—Is it dead, Mary?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, miss, you have killed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I!—I have killed it!—I that loved it so!—Oh! how un∣happy I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Don't cry so, miss, you was not so much to blame now.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Dear Juliet, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! cousin, why did you leave me?—I am never so naugy when you are with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: My dear, I have been seeking you, at last I heard you was playing with Fanny Wood, so then I sat down to write to mama—But what has happened?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Oh Miss Juliet has been in one of her usual furies.—I must dress.—I am tired out with her.—Mary will tell you, Miss Paulina.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary,
SP.P: And 'tis as much your fault as her's this time, I must say, teaze, teaze, for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Mary, what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Shall I tell, miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! my cousin will hate me.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I hate you, my dear, no shall pity you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Why, miss, my young lady was feeding her bird, and rt it somehow, and 'tis dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: No, Paulina, that is not all; I was angry with my poor bird, I gave it a sudden squeeze, and killed it.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: My dear cousin, you almost redeem your faults by this openness of heart.—How I pity you, how much you must feel on this occasion!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: But you, who are so good, how much you must detest me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: To tell you the truth, Miss Paulina, my young lady was not so much to blame as she is sometimes. Mrs. Selwyn did teaze her sadly, that she did, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
But that was not my
bird's fault!—Ah, my poor bird, he will never eat out of my hand again!—How could I be so cruel as to hurt a little creature who loved me so dearly.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Leave us, Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Do not distress your∣self so much, my dear Juliet.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Do I not deserve to be distressed?

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: You have certainly been wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah! You do not know half how naughty I have been: I pinched Mary, I beat Fanny Wood!—What is it makes me so wicked, Paulina? I always know when I am so, and I am unhappy, then I fret, and do wrong again.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
I can easily conceive
all that, you are greatly to be piti∣ed.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: But you are the only person (except my father) who e∣ver speaks to me as if I had com∣mon sense!—Mary shrugs up her shoulders and leaves me as soon as she can.—Mrs. Selwyn laughs at me and treats me like a baby. It was but just now she bade me "look how my doll stared at me!" And that put me into such a pas∣sion, that I threw my doll across the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
Certainly Mrs. Sel∣wyn does not treat you properly, but that does not justify you. You are now, my dear, more than twelve years old; at that age, though children, we are no longer babies, but you do not seek to improve yourself. You read, indeed, be∣cause you love reading, but not
with a steady view to your own improvement, and almost all the remainder of your time is spent in dressing your doll and playing with Fanny Wood, who is too ignorant to be a proper companion for you; thus you tempt others to treat you like a baby.—I do not offend you?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: No, no,—I like to hear you because you speak to me gently, and I feel what you say. Pray, dear Paulina, tell me what I must do to be like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
My dear Juliet, I wish you a better example;—if you were with us, mama would soon teach you to be all your friends could wish.—But Juliet, with the understanding nature has given you, you may do much for yourself. In the words of a very great author I will tell you that
—"There is no soul
More ableto direct you than yourself,
If with the sap of Reason you would quench
Or but allay the Fire of Passion!"—

DIV2.P: Read more, and reflect.—When∣ever you find yourself getting an∣gry leave the cause of your dis∣pleasure, take a book which amu∣ses you, and read till you find your∣self calm and easy. Struggle with your violent passions, and think to what dreadful consequences they will lead if you indulge them.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Consequences!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
Yes, my dear cousin, I know not to what an excess they may transport you in time, if they are not now opposed.—My mother told me, the other day, she had just read the history of a man, who, when a boy, squeezed his squirrel to death
as you did your bird, and when he grew up, after various crimes, be∣ing angry with his wife, his child, who was in her arms, happened to cry while he was speaking and, in a fit of passion, he laid his hand on it, and strangled it in a moment!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! Heaven, how shocking; do you think it possible, Paulina, do you think it possible I should ever do so?

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
It is impossible to say to what extravagance passion may lead!—But yesterday you would have detested the idea of injuring your bird—and are we not told i the Bible, that when the Prophet foretold to HazaelSee 8th Chapter of the 2d Book of Kings. the miseries he would bring on his country, and the cruelties of which he would be
guilty, he exclaimed, "Is thy ser∣vant a dog that he should do this great thing?"—And yet when he gave way to his passions, he exactly verified the Prophet's words.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh, Paulina! you te∣rify me extremely—I will indeed try to be good—I will not beat Fanny, nor pinch Charles any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I wish you may not—It is time for us to dress, your father will be at home presently, and I hear Charles is just come from school.

DIV2.HEAD: THE Misfortunes of Anger.
PART II.
DIV2.STAGE: Juliet enters from the garden, she draws a chair, sits down, and leans her head on her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
I HAVE a sad head-ach, it always comes when I cry so much.—How true is what Paulina said just now, that I make myself wretched by indulging my passions!—Why did nobody ever tell me so before?—She takes a picture from her bosom and kisses it.—Oh, my dear mother!—You died too early to form by your example, the
daughter you loved so tenderly!—Wretched girl!—Why do I ever, for a moment, forget the character which my father drew of my mother when he gave me this picture.—"Be like your mo∣ther, my Juliet; she was mild and gentle to all, she was beloved by every one who knew her! her dy∣ing wish was, that you might be virtuous!—My child, be worthy of your mother!—Yes, those were exactly his words. Ah! how little do I fulfil her wishes!—I, who ill-treat the servant to whose care she intrusted my infancy—Who a∣buse a poor child whose situation should make me pity her!—I whom every body hates!—Torn by contrary feelings!—Capable of knowing when I do wrong, yet yielding to the next temptation.—In spite of my faults, am I not to be pitied?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Miss, my master bade me tell you he is going to Mr. Richley's, and shall be back in less than an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: What is the matter miss, you are crying?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I have reason to cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I am sure, miss, I don't know any young lady who might be happier.—You have the best of fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah! that is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: And here you have a fine house, where you are, as one may say, mistress, and a carriage, and every earthly thing you can wish.—Only think of the poor children down in the village: the little Wood's whose mother is so sick, and who are half starved!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Alas, yes!—And I have ill-treated poor Fanny!—My dear Mary, do go down to the village and give her this shilling; I will beg papa, presently, to send our a∣pothecary to her mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh, miss, what a pity you are not always good, how eve∣ry body would love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I hope they will in fu∣ture.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Juliet, what are you going to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I am going to read to Mrs. Selwyn, in her own room, and afterwards Charles and I are going to play.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Very well, then I will finish my letter to mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
Do so.—I shall not stay long with Mrs. Selwyn.—Let
me know, Mary, when my father comes in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Miss Juliet seems very unhappy to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Yes, she has naturally a strong sense of what is right; she feels that she is wrong, and of course is unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I cannot help loving her, though she is sometimes so much out of the way. She was a sweet child before she grew so passionate, and she has a great deal of good about her still. How my poor lady would have grieved had she lived to see her o head-strong.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
Had it pleased Hea∣ven to spare Mrs. Beecher, Juliet would probably have been a very
different character; she has an ad∣mirable understanding, but she is ill educated.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: That's true, indeed, miss. I take the liberty of speak∣ing to you because you know how I love all his family, and that I have lived in it long enough to know something about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Yes, Mary, you may speak to me without fear; I know your attachment to your late lady and all that belonged to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Ah, miss, I wish my young lady lived with you, you are so mild and so sensible, and my lady your mother is so fine a char∣acter—

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I have reason to glo∣ry in my mother—May I be one day like her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P:
You will, miss, ay, you are already; truly I hear of you
from all parts.—But I know yo don't wish to be praised.—What I was going to say, is this:—Nobo∣dy hears us?—No.—Indeed, Miss Paulina, Mrs. Selwyn is not fit to have the care of my young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: It is true indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: She sets her no example but laziness, and she teazes her out of her wits;—if you had but heard her this morning—

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
I see it with pain. She has no command over my cou∣sin, because she puts herself on a le∣vel with her by mean teazing and raillery;—a passionate temper was never mended by irritation.—By the way, I don't much like this scheme of playing with Charles; Juliet and he always quarrel, and I am afraid he will overthrow all her good resolutions. I mean to speak to my uncle, to-night, about Mrs.
Selwyn, not to blame or censure her, but merely to say I think she does not exactly follow the right method of managing my cousin's temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Truly I think not.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I intend to ask my un∣cle to et Juliet return with me, I know mama wishes it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I wish e may, miss, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Well, I will go and write my letter.
SP.STAGE: (She is going, when Juliet rushes in apparently much terrified.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh Paulina!—Mary!—Help, help!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh dear, miss what, is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: My brother!—help—help him!—go to him.
SP.STAGE: (Mary runs out, Juliet sinks down with her head against a chair, Paulina goes to her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Cousin!—My dear Juliet, what is the matter?—Oh, Heaven! she is fainting!—What shall I do, shall I run to Charles?—No, I cannot leave this dear girl.—Juliet, revive, smell to my salts.—(Juliet recovering, rises on her knees, and clings round Pauli∣na.)

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh, Paulina!—Send for some help.—Run to my father.—My father!—Good Heaven! he will hate me for ever.—I shall be banished his sight; plead for me Paulina!—Wretched girl!—What will become of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: For pity's sake tell me what you have done?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: What have I done?—I know not!—Perhaps I have ki∣ed my brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina
SP.P: Unhappy girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh! well may you shud∣der, well may you look at me with horror!—You who warned me; how dare I clasp my arms round you.—Those hands, which, (how can I live to tell it) perhaps have murdered my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: With what terror do I hear her, (She leans over her.) Wretched victim of ungovern'd passion!—Revive, fear not my re∣proaches!—Ah, thou art already too miserable!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Ah, miss, what shall we do?—I have sent for a surgeon.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: How is he hurt?

SP.SPEAKER: Mary
SP.P: Alas! I know not how much, the knife has struck him near the eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: The knife!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P:
Yes, they were at play and quarrelled, Miss Juliet had a
knife in her hand, which she threw at him.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina
SP.P: How dreadful!—let us run to him!—Yet, Juliet! But why should I seek to revive her!—Unhappy creature, she wakes but to woe—Perhaps he may be blind∣ed!—I stiffen with horror!—Ah I hear the surgeon; follow me, Mary!

DIV2.P:
Paulina, where am I!—You will not speak!—What have I done!—Ah I remember—too, too well I remember!—(She raises her∣self)—They are gone!—They leave me!—to die alone!—Alas I deserve it!—Am I worthy that one creature should pity me!—Yet the torments I endure!—Can they atone for my crimes?—Ne∣ver, never!—Dreadful idea!—must I suffer thro' life the anguish I
feel at this moment?—Thro' life—what terrible fears crowd upon me!—(She kneels,) Oh God of mer∣cy! hear me, pity me!—Ah He is a God of justice!—Can he for∣give me who have murdered my Brother?—What a wretch am I!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Miss Juliet, are you better?

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Yes, Mary.—Have you seen—

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Your brother?—yes, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah, you weep!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Truly yes, I am fright∣ened to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I am the unhappy cause.—I dread to hear—I dare not ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: The surgeon is with him; I could not stay any longer to see him suffer so.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Suffer!

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Yes, the surgeon is o∣bliged to hurt him, to find if the wound is—I cannot speak it.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Mortal you would say? How is it that I have courage to pronounce that horrible word?—Ah, I gather courage from the ex∣cess of my despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Oh my poor master, what will he say!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Do not distract me!—Pity for a moment the pangs I suffer!—Leave me, Mary, leave me, I implore you!—Go, learn it there is any hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
I have lost every∣thing!—My father will drive me from him for ever—I shall quit every thing I love!—My friends, my relations will blush when my name is mentioned—Never mo
shall I revisit these scenes, so dear to my infancy!—Let me not re∣call the years I have past—years of innocence and happiness!—Go where I will, I shall be pointed at and hated.—Even the picture of my mother, which used in all my distresses to console me, I can never see again.—I should fancy it re∣proached me.—And all this mise∣ry I have incurred by one moment of passion!—Oh God, if thou should'st this once deign to save me, never, never, will I be guilty again!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Juliet!—my dear cousin!—be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah! what then!—What!—may I, dare I hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Yes—the surgeon says he is in no danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet
SP.P: Oh my best Paulina!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina,
SP.P: I ran to you the instant I heard it.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I have not deserved your goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Ah Juliet!—if the knife had gone ever so little on one side, Charles would have been kil∣led, or on the other, and he would have been blinded for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh merciful Almighty God!—from what misery has thy providence preserved me!—even now I cannot behold myself with∣out horror.—Have I deserved the mercy I have met with?—No!—tho' innocent in intention, my action was guilty.—I could not wish to hurt my brother, yet took the means to do so!—Detested passion!—Oh Paulina, I am cured for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
I dare hope so!—
The lessons of this day have been striking.—They shew how one step in evil leads to another.—Aweful and horrid might have been the e∣vent, but as it has proved, we will hope this instruction has been di∣rected by Providence, to warn you of your danger!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: It has done it com∣pletely.—But Paulina, where is my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I hear him now in the hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh Paulina, I dare not see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I will go to him, and I hope, return with your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: My best friend—let actions speak my gratitude, deign but to counsel and direct me, henceforth I will be guided by you alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Well, Miss Juliet, make yourself easy, all goes well.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Thank God!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You have had good fortune, Miss, I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Good fortune, Ma'am! I dare to consider it as the act of Divine Providence, if not to save me, yet to preserve my father from misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You improve, Miss, your language is really fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Misfortunes correct the heart, and strong feelings excite strong expression.—I hope I shall improve.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You astonish me—you who but this morning were dressing your doll, to be making wis remarks, is indeed surprising.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I am not a fool, tho' I have acted like one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P:
No, no, they an't very
wise that take you for a fool. I have often heard you talk to my master as sensible as any-body is the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: Miss Juliet ne∣ver indulged me with any of her sensible conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: Truly no, because y treated her like a baby.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: You take great liberties.

SP.SPEAKER: Mary.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, Ma'am, but I have often told you you did not know my young lady so well as I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Selwyn.
SP.P: The more sense she has, the more shame for her to behave as she has done.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P:
Too true indeed!—my conscience tells me I have not the excuse of foly.—But I have suf∣fered passion to over-run and darken all my good qualities. This one
hour has driven it from my heart. I am no longer a foolish child.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Come, my dearest Juliet—Charles is with your fa∣ther, he knows all, he forgives you, he calls for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: I owe every-thing to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I have more good news for you—one word.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Selwyn and Mary retire to the back of the Scene.) You go home with me—you are to stay with us as long as you please!

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Delightful!—

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Your father dismisses Mrs. Selwyn.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Ah I am sorry! She is poor, and she has taught me ma∣ny things.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P:
My good cousin, how
I love that gratitude!—your fa∣ther will allow her a pension, we have settled all that since I left you.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: Oh my best cousin!—how much do I owe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: I am overpaid if you are happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Juliet.
SP.P: To be so I must be good.—That will be the work of your hands!—How will you be loved by your friends, by your mother, by Heaven itself!—yes that will repay you.

SP.SPEAKER: Paulina.
SP.P: Let us go, my uncle expects us.

Q.L: —Exclamations, tender tones, fond tears,
And all the graceful drap'ry Pity wears,
These are not Pity's self, they but express
Her inward suff'rings, by her pictured dress;
And these fair marks, reluctant I relate,
These lovely symbols may be counterfeit.

DIV2.HEAD: SENSIBILITY.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a Dressing-room, at Mrs. Melville's. A Table standing with Work, and Books.)
Enter Mrs. Rivers, Cecilia, and Martha.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: PRAY, ma'am, walk in, I will let my mistress know you are here, she is walking in the garden with Miss Melville.—Won't you please to sit?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Rivers.
SP.P: Thank you Mar∣tha, don't hurry your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia
SP.P: This is a pretty room, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: Very much so, I see it again with great pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: It is some time, I think, since you were here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs, Rivers.
SP.P: Yes, near two years. Mrs. Melville has been gone so long on business of her late husband's to an estate he had in Jamaica.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: How glad you will be to see her again! What a delight∣ful day we shall spend?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: It will indeed give me great pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: But her daughter!—Oh, mama, what joy to her to see her mother again after an absence of two years!—I should envy her, if I had not passed those two years with the best of mothers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
She has indeed
probably lost much by so long an absence from her who is so well a∣ble to instruct her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Undoubtedly!—Ah, whose instructions can teach the heart so soon as those of a mother, whose reproofs proceed from affec∣tion, whose praises are the greatest glory of a child!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
It is true,—a child must be obstinate indeed, who refuses to listen to the instructions of a fond mother.—Mrs. Melville is entitled to her daughter's best affections, not only by the good∣ness of her heart and understanding, but by the sacrifices she has made for her sake.—When Mr. Melville died, he left his large estate in Jamaica to his little girl: on in∣quiry, her mother found that the estate had been, and still was, ill managed by the steward; in short,
that nothing but the presence of some person interested in its im∣provement could render it half so valuable as it had been supposed.—She determined, therefore, to over∣come her dread of the sea, which all her life had been extreme; to leave her friends, her sister, even her child, in England, and under∣take the voyage herself.—This she has done; has restored the estate to the most flourishing condition, and is now returned to enjoy the re∣ward of her labours.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: What a charming cha∣racter!—(A short pause.) I like this room very much, 'tis so pleasant and quiet—(She rises and walks a∣bout)—Mama, may I look at this book?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
If you please, a it is lying open to every-one's in∣spection, it cannot be improper, but
it is impertinent and ill-bred to look even into printed books, which are placed out of immediate view.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: "The Beauties of Sterne!"—It has Miss Melville's name in it.—I do not know this book, Mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: No, my dear, tho' it has great merit in point of writing and sentiment, it is not ex∣actly the book I should chuse for you at present. In my opinion it recommends too much the enervat∣ing mind of Sensibility, to which I so greatly object.—But here come Mrs. Melville and Isabella.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: My dear friend, how much I rejoice to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
The pleasure is mutual, believe me!—It is so long since we met, I began to fear we should meet no more!—This is, I
believe, Miss Melville, but so grown I should hardly have known her!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Not more than Miss Rivers.—I must have the young people acquainted.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Melville introduces Cecilia and Isabella to each other, they curtsy, and seem to talk apart.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: I hope they will be so, nothing can give me more pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: But I forget to beg your pardon for keeping you waiting, I had strolled beyond the garden into the field, and Mar∣tha could not find me.—She has shown you into a litter'd room.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: No apology is necessary, I have long known and loved this room.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: It is my daugh∣ter's now, I gave it up to her the day after my return, and she has already brought hither her books and work—so that she has the confusion to answer for—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: It is a becoming confusion, I like to see books and work about in a young person's a∣partment.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Mine would have been in better order, mama, if you had not called me away suddenly.—Besides I hardly know where I am, or what I do at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: I dare say, my dear, you have hardly yet recover∣ed, if I may o express myself, the happiness of seeing your mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P:
No indeed, Ma'am!—The extreme joy almost over∣come me. It may well be called recovery, for such delight is really
suffering!
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Rivers looks at her wih some surprise.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Mine was, and still is, exquisite!—To return once more to my friends, to my sister, to my daughter, is happiness so great as wholly to repay me all I have suffered in my absence from them!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: No doubt, every sacrifice we make of pleasure to duty will, sooner or later, be re∣paid; even the conviction of hav∣ing done so carries with it a com∣fort to the heart superior to all the advantages to be derived from a deviation from virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P:
You say true. It was with extreme regret that I prepared to quit England, and to leave my daughter; but the assurance that my departure was necessary to her future welfare, the
dread of endangering her health, then extremely delicate, by take∣ing her with me, and the convic∣tion that I left her in proper care, conspired to determine me, and I am now repaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: But, mama, I should have been so afraid of the sea and storms!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Go, you are a silly child, to form such a terrible idea of dangers, which princi∣pally imaginary.—But, my dear Mrs. Rivers, will you go with me to my greenhouse?—I have some curious West-India plants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: With all my heart.—Children, will you stay here, or go with us?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Oh, they shall remain here.—They will become better acquainted in our absence.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Rivers and Mrs. Melville go out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Let us sit down, my dear Miss Rivers. (They sit.)—What pleasure I hope to derive from your aquaintance!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: My mother I am sure will be happy in my forming an intimacy with you, she has so high an opinion of Mrs. Melville!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: It will give me infi∣nite pleasure.—Suffer me to say I already feel I shall love you ex∣tremely, I am already attached to you.—Dear Cecilia, may I believe the impression is mutual!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I have no doubt, on a farther acquaintance, my gratitude for your kindness will ripen into real regard.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: You are very good!—(She assumes a melancholy air.)—Hitherto I have been very un∣fortunate in my friendships!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia,
SP.P: You are very young to complain of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella,
SP.P: Alas yes!—The misfortune of too great sensibility is mine.—You can have no idea what I have suffered—what I do at this moment suffer!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: You alarm and dis∣tress me.—What at your age can have happened to make you so un∣easy?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella,
SP.P: Alas, my dear Cecilia, amidst all my joy for the return of my mother, I endure severe regret, bitter anguish I might call it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Good Heaven! on what account.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella,
SP.P: A∣miable girl!—I see you sympa∣thize with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
I do indeed, but sure∣ly
you would not have told me so much without intending to explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: No, my sweet friend.The inflated and strong language Isabella uses, is one symptom of False Sensibility.—To apply violent terms on common occasions is equally absurd and unnatural—From your tenderness I expect the only consolation of which my situation is capable.—How will your kind and gentle nature pity me when you hear the loss I have sustained!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: What can it be, when your mother is still with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P:
At the seat of my aunt, where I have been during my mother's absence, I contracted a strong and ardent attachment to a young lady about your age.—I even think you resemble her,—
you have the same softness of com∣plexion, the same sweet smile!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Ah, my dear Isabella, I will spare you the relation.—I guess too easily what you have suffered!—It is true I have never formed any friendship out of my own family, but I can conceive what its feelings must be.—And have you really lost, for e∣ver, a tie so tender?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Not, I hope, for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: How!—I have mis∣understood you.—I believe you meant to have said she was dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh no!—I should hardly be able to survive so great a misfortune.—Is it not enough to be separated from her?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: You fear you shall, perhaps, meet her no more!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: No.—She is to spend the greatest part of the summer with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I do not understand—what then do you lament?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: What?—Surely her absence at present!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: What the absence of a few months do you regret so deeply!—I profess you surprise me!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella,
SP.P: But I have been so accustomed to see her every day, she is so charm∣ing—and my misfortune is too great sensibility!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
Can sensibility become a misfortune and a torment?—I have been taught to consider it as the source of goodness and delight—True, indeed, we may be some∣times severely pained by the im∣possibility of relieving those whom we pity, by the illness of friends, and various other circumstances, but at the same time an active wish
to do good warms and cheas the heart, and when we ste our an∣guish and carefully attend the sick∣bed of those we love, do we not feel such comfort as half repays us for the sorrow we endure in seeing them suffer!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: But unfortunately I feel so much. I can do very little to relieve the pain of those I love; my presence of mind forsakes me, and I become unable to assist them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: But pardon me for say∣ing that it is a sort of weakness a∣gainst which we ought to struggle, our feeling becomes useless, worse than useless; it disables us if it does does not prompt us to action. We might as well not feel for the unhappy, as not seek to relieve them.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: I sympathise with them, but my spirits are so weak I can do little more.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I protest I do not un∣derstand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Oh, dear Miss Mel∣ville, a sad thing has happened!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh Heavens! what? You alarm me beyond expression!

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Don't be too much frightened, miss, 'tis well it's no worse, but you will be vexed?—

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: I entreat you to tell me what has happened at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Why, miss, your pret∣ty parrot has hurt himself sadly.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Ah! my poor parrot, what has he done?

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P:
Miss, he was stand∣ing upon his perch, when a great dog followed the baker into the kitchen, Poll was frigtened, and flew to the window, dash'd him∣self against a pane of glass, broke
it and cut himself very much with the pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella,
SP.P: Oh? what shall I do, what shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: My dear Isabella, don't distress yourself so,—I dare say he will soon be well again,—let us go and see if we can do any thing for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh! I cannot bear to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Dear miss, he will soon be well, but somebody should put something to the cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Martha, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: I would with all my heart, Miss, but I burned my hand so yesterday I cannot hold him, and our silly cook is afraid of his biting her.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Will Thomas?

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Thomas is not at home, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Dear Isabella, I will do it—'tis true I shall be sorry to see the poor creature in pain, but I cannot bear the idea of not assisting him.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: You are extremely good!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Poor thing! he is suf∣fering all this time. Come, my dear, let us go to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh, I cannot see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Not see him!

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Dear Miss, the poor thing knows you, and he will be quiet if you are by.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh, but indeed it wil make me ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Pooh, pooh, a run in the garden will soon make you well again!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: What spirits you have!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
To be sure—that is
natural at my age—what have I to be melancholy about?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: You are very happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: You have as much cause to be happy as I have; but come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: That's a charming young lady!—How she runs along and how chearful she looks!—What ails Miss Isabella, I wonder; she always looks sorrowful, and sighs, and walks so slowly, I see that already.—Truly, that is un∣natural at her age.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Martha, where are the young ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Marry, Ma'am, they are gone to see the poor Parrot; he has hurt himself, and they are gone to help him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melvillie.
SP.P: Very well, they are well employed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: My dear friend, I am so charmed to see you, and so anxious to talk with you, that I fear I shall quite fatigue you with prate!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: Not at all; as∣sure yourself I am too much inte∣rested in all which concerns you, and am indeed eager to have an unrestrained conversation with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: I am equally eager; and as the first subject to a fond mother is her child, we will talk of ours. I am not quite sa∣tisfied with Isabella.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: How so?—She appears gentle and sensible!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P:
Yes, she has many good qualities, but I see
with pain, that one of the most amiable, she carries to an excess which makes me wish she possessed it not: it gives her so much pain, and will thro' life be so often a source of distress to her, that I could almost wish to suppress it entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: Pray tell me what it is—you really alarm me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Sensibility.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: I am amazed!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Melville.
SP.P: I once hardly could have believed I should wish a child of mine to want Sensibility; but I see in Isabella how much it tends to increase the unavoidable distresses of human life, even to create them where they are not; so that I really think had I ano∣ther child to educate, I should la∣bour as much as possible to suppress this pleasing, but unhappy quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Rivers.
SP.P:
I must repeat, you amaze me!—What! Sensibility!—The first and best gift of Heaven—would you rob your child of that?—Not only is it the sweetest grace of youth, but the principal source of its virtues.—Can you conceive any great or good action which has ever been performed by a per∣son wanting Sensibility? Did you ever hear of any really great charac∣ter who wanted this endowment? Have I then a right to rob my child of that which alone can lead to exalted virtue, and to the train of delight by which it is accom∣panied?—How sweetly, as well as truly, says a certain charming Au∣thoress,
Cold and ert the mental powers would lie.
Without this quick'ning spark of De∣ity
To draw the rich materials from the mine,
To bid the mass of intellect refine;
To melt the firm, to animate the cold,
And Heav'n's own impress stamp on Nature's gold;
To give immortal Mind its firmest tone,
Oh Sensibility!—is all thine own!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: I agree with you fully, my dear friend, as to the graces and charms of Sensibility; but allow me to differ from you a moment. Was not Cato a great character, yet had he sensibility, who did not shed a tear over the bo∣dy of his son, just slain in battle?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
Undoubtedly yes.—First we ought to consider the education which was given to the Romans.—We ought to re∣collect that their country was the chief object of their love, and that they were taught to despise all considerations which interfered
with their duty to that.—Thus when Cato saw the dead body of his son, he did not weep, because true Sensibility exalted his mind to the height of patriotism, which made him willingly yield his son a victim to Rome.—He wished also to encourage the sinking Romans, by making their lives less valuable in their eyes, when he, to whom they looked for example, could so chearfully par with that life which was dearer to him than his own.—What but Sensibility could have awakened this high sense of duty, and heroic resolution?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: But that is ex∣actly what I complain of, Sensibili∣ty, at least the sensibility I am used to see, enervates and weakens the mind; it destroys this heroic resolution, this preference of duty to indulgence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: "The Sensibility you are used to see," these words explain to me your meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: You think then there are two kinds of Sensi∣bility?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
Undoubtedly.—Or rather I should say that which is commonly dignified with that charming name, is unworthy of it; and if you will allow me to say so, by what I have seen of Miss Melville's, that is the Sensi∣bility she possesses, though perhaps mixed and blended with the true mind. Let us refer again to the delightful Authoress I have al∣ready quoted, whose every line contains meaning and reason.
Tis not to mourn because a Sparrow dies,
To rave in artificial extasis! I would have Sensibility a spring of
Action. I would have it directed to a generous, firm line of Conduct. In short, it should be Principle re∣fined and pointed. I would have young people taught to treat every creature with mercy and kindness, but I would not have them waste their tenderness and affection on a set of Animals. I would have them anxious to relieve every thing in distress, but I would not have them
Boast quick rapture trembling in their eye,
If from the Spider's web they save a Fly. Far would I be from wishing them to have the word Sensibility contin∣ually in their mouths, tho' I would never for an instant have it quit their hearts. It ought to animate, not deject them; to strengthen, not enervate their minds.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P:
You are per∣fectly
right, my dear friend but how shall we teach young people to draw the line?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P:
By not suffering them to pass it, without reprehen∣sion; by not praising them for feeling, by not allowing them to exaggerate their language, which leads to that hateful exaggeration of Sentiment I so much dislike.—Accustomed to express themselves strongly, to say they "love," they "detest"—they are in "anguish," in "extasy," they strive to make their feelings correspond with their words: if they succeed, their im∣aginations become inflamed and de∣lusive; if they do not, they are perpetually affected and unnatural.—Let them ask themselves, whe∣ther they really feel what they ex∣press, when they say they love or hate any-thing; let them first con∣sider
whether it is worth loving or hating, and then whether they really do love or hate it: they will then not be so easily deceived them∣selves, which, I believe, generally is the case before they seek to de∣ceive others.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: I am sure you are right, and I shall earnestly press this knowledge of herself on Isa∣bella.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Rivers.
SP.P: I have always done so with Cecilia; and I wish young people would consider how much more amiable, simple unaf∣fected manners are, than that pom∣pous prentence of feeling and ten∣derness of which some are so fond.

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: The dinner is ready, Ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Very well, we are coming.

DIV2.HEAD: SENSIBILITY.
PART II.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: THIS room is cooler than the dining parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: It is remarkably plea∣sant and quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Come let us it, I am wretchedly out of spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I saw with great con∣cern that you appeared out of spir∣its at dinner, and that your mama looked uneasy at it.—What is the matter, are you not well?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P:
Yes, well—that is tolerably well—but the sight of
my poor Parrot this morning has made me quite unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: But, my dear, you ought not to suffer it to do so!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Bless me! can I feel as I please?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: In a great measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: I am glad you think so.—Then you are never unhappy I suppose, for I believe nobody would chuse to be so!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Pardon me.—There are cases in which we must feel unhap∣py, whether we struggle against it or not: but do you not think much of our unhappiness depends on our indulging melancholy, or striving against it?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Perhaps it may, but why will you not allow the present to be one of the cases you mention?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
I cannot think it of consequence enough. It is true I pity the poor bird, and if I were
attached to him, as I dare say you are, I should be extremely concern∣ed, but still as my concern would do him no good, and as I had done all I could to relieve him, I should strive against it, and make myself easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella
SP.P: But I cannot—it makes me unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: That is what it ought not to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Do you make no al∣lowance for the difference of dispo∣sitions?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Yes,—but I also be∣lieve we can greatly correct and after our own.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: And you think I need this correction?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: You are not angry with me!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: No—but

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
Nay, that is unfair—
we were speaking generally—you asked my sentiments, or I should not have given them; if I have offended you I sincerely beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: No, no, you have not offended me—yet I will own much less than what you have said would have offended me in some people; but you speak so sensibly, and with so much goodness, I love to hear you tho' it is to blame me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I did not mean to blame you: I could not think of taking that liberty.—Let us drop the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: No, no, we will drop it.—I shall think you are an∣gry, if you do not tell me all you think.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: What would you have me tell you?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P:
Whether I really, in
your opinion, require the correction you talk of?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I have not a right, on so short an acquaintance, to de∣cide.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: You will not tell me—but I beg of you to be sincere!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Well then remember you have no right to be offended.—I do think you suffer your feel∣ings to govern you too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Well I will not dis∣pute the word suffer, since you say I might correct it, but tell me how?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Are you convinced the correction is necessary?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Perhaps not entirely.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Permit me to ask you a few questions.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Suppose your mother, or any of your friends, were ill, what would you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: I should be very much grieved!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Of course—but should you attend to them yourself, or how should you act?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: I should wish to at∣tend them, but I fear I should be too unhappy!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: If you were yourself ill, how should you expect your mother to act?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh I know very well she would attend me constantly!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Well, do you not be∣lieve she would feel a great deal?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh yes, I am sure of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Should you not be very much distress'd, if, instead of at∣tending you, she disturbed you by continual sighs and tears, and rendered herself so incapable of assisting be obliged to leave you to the care of servants?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Certainly!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: The inference is so obvious, I will leave you to draw it for your self.—Only let me hint, if every-body felt as you say you do, and acted in consequence, what would become of those who are sick, or in danger?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: You are certainly right—but how am I to conquer this excessive feeling?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Simply by not indulging it—Perhaps your mind will some∣times turn itself from a suffering object; but do not heed it.—Force it to act.—Do not say "I cannot"—but try.—Think you can, and you will be able.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Do you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
I am even sure of it.—I will give you an instance; I am myself extremely afraid of Fire! and used to tell my mama I believed
if my bed were on fire, I should be burnt for want of resolution to move. She took a great deal of pains to reason me out of this be∣lief, which she foresaw might be so dangerous.—Last summer, when we were at my aunt's, I was one evening in my own room, which joins the nursery, where her little girl was sleeping, the nursery maid was just gone down stairs, I smelt fire, and running into the nursery, saw that the cat had jumped on a table where the maid had placed a candle, and had beat the candle into the cradle where the baby was—the quilt was in a blaze!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh mercy!—what did you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
My first impulse was to run for help, but struck with the idea that the infant would be burnt stifled before help could arrive,
I said to myself "Oh mama, let me now remember your lessons!"—I flew to the cradle, snatched up a small carpet, and threw into the cradle; it extinguished the flame: I then seized the child, and ran with her down stairs.—You may suppose that my mother and aunt thought me distracted; but when I explained to them what had happened, I thought my aunt would never cease thanking and praising me.—She told me I had saved her from despair and distrac∣tion; that her child should be taught to love me as a second mo∣ther.—I short I cannot repeat to you half she said, or describe the painful delight I felt in her grati∣tude and joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: But did you not suf∣fer from the fright?

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P:
A little.—I felt sick
and faint; mama gave me some drops, and I cried a good deal; after which I was quite well, and never can think myself grateful enough to Heaven, for giving me courage to rescue the poor infant!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Well, I admire you!—but I fear I should never be able to imitate you!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Only give me your promise that you will try, and I am sure you will be able.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Melville and Mrs. Ri∣vers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: So my dear girls you have run away from us!—In∣deed the dining parlour is so warm, that we re glad to quit it also.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: It is very warm in∣deed, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I am afraid you are not well,

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Not very well indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh, mama, what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: Are you saint?—Sit down.
SP.STAGE: (She places a chair, and Mrs. Mel∣ville is down.)

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Speak to me mama!—Oh, what shall I do!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: My dear, you alarm your mama she will be better presently; I will fetch some wa∣ter.

STAGE.HI: (She runs out. Mrs. Rivers gives her to Mrs. Melville, who becomes more and more faint. Isabella runs about distractedly and crying.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: My dear Isabella, don't be so frightened! Open the window, and bathe your mother's forehead with this Hungary water.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh I cannot, indeed I cannot, I am so frighten'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: Silly girl, how can you be such a coward!
SP.STAGE: (Cecilia returns with water. Mar∣tha comes in; they sprinkle Mrs. Melville with water. Cecilia supports her. Isabella continues cry∣ing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: Isabella, I am quite ashamed of you—how can you be so childish!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh, mama is dying, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs.. Rivers.
SP.P: Dying!—what nonsense!—she is even now recov∣ering.—My dear friend, are you better?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Yes, I am bet∣ter, I thank you.—My eyes are still dim.—Who is this supporting me?—My dear Isabella!—Dear child, do not be alarmed, I am better!
SP.STAGE: (Isabella advances. Cecilia makes signs to her come forward.)

SP.SPEAKER: Martha.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, we are all frightened, Miss Isabella is as bad as you almost!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville,
SP.P: Don't be frighted, my love; I am better indeed,—I ought to be well, when you are so attentive to me—Ah! what happiness for a mother to be supported in the arms of her child.—I feel your tears on my face, speak to me Isabella.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella,

STAGE.HI: (falling on her before her mother, and kissing her hands)

SP.P: Ah mama, I am here!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Who then is this?—Cecilia!—It is to you then that I am obliged for assistance! (A short pause, during which Isabella appears much confused.)—Thank you, my dear.—I am subject to these attacks in warm weather, but I am now well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: My dear Mrs. Melville, had you not better go to your own room?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: I will present∣ly; you and Cecilia will have the goodness to assist me?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Ah mama, why do you not say Isabella will assist me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: We naturally look for help towards those from whom we have received it.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Ah mama, it is true indeed I have not been so happy as to be of use to you, but can you believe I did not wish it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: We can only judge of the heart by the actions it produces.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia,
SP.P: Dear ma'am, if you could have seen Isabella's distress, her alarm—she is incapa∣ble.—Oh can you believe your child could neglect you!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Generous girl! how I love that amiable warmth.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Mother, my dearest mother forgive me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: If you are conscious of no offence, why ask forgiveness?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Can I think myself innocent, when you are displeased with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Rivers.
SP.P: How amiable is that sentiment! It must procure your pardon.—My dear friend, be∣lieve me, Isabella suffered exceed∣ingly; her distress alone caused that appearance of neglect you condemn.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: If too much feeling, or too little cause the same effect, ought they not to be equally condemned?

SP.SPEAKER: Ms. Rivers.
SP.P:
If not equally, both ought to be.—But this is not
a time to argue.—You will in∣crease your indisposition by talking, and at least Isabella cannot feel your displeasure too much.—For∣give her, I beg of you!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Dearest madam, for∣give Isabella.—Look at her; can you see her distress, and not pity her?—Her constitution is slight; the alarm was too much for her.—Her extreme affection for you was the cause of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: Rise, my dear girl, I forgive the apparent slight.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Oh believe, believe it could not proceed from my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P:
Let us speak of it no more, but correct and suppress in future, I beg of you, that excess of feeling, which renders you incapable of doing your duty.—Come, my
dear friend, you will have the the goodness to go with me into my own room.—I will lie down awhile.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Mama, will you not suffer me to assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: If I do not, my dear, it is not because I am still angry with you; but because I do not need your attendance: in less than an hour I dare say I shall be well enough to meet you at the tea-table.—This faintness has only been owing to the heat; I have felt it all day.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: And yet you have not complained.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Melville.
SP.P: No, since com∣plaining could not cool the air, and consequently could not relieve my faintness.—Stay here, my child, with Cecilia, and both of you re∣cover yourselves before I return.

STAGE.HI: (Mrs. Melville, Mrs. Rivers, and Martha go out.)

DIV2.STAGE: (Isabella its down, and leans her head on her hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: My dear, will you take a little hartshorn and water?

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: No, thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Be easy, my dear girl since your mama is quite reconciled to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Ah Cecilia, if I had but recollected your kind and wife counsels, I should not have incur∣ed her displeasure!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: In future, you will, I doubt not, act otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P:
I hope so!—Never let me again incur a pang so severe as that I felt when my mother spoke of the sweetness of being assisted by her child, when I had
not been of the least service to her.—And again, when she said "You and Cecilia will assist me"—as if I were not there! as if, alas, but too justly, I were a useless, help∣less being!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: Let us drop these un∣pleasant ideas, and hope that the consequence will be a fixed resolu∣tion on your part to encourage for∣titude and activity, and to repress enervating and excessive feeling.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: It shall indeed; and still, dear Cecilia, counsel and ad∣vise me. Be as sincere as I have hitherto found you; be my moni∣tor, my adviser, and my advocate.—Dear girl, (embracing her) how I ever enough thank you for thse generous tears you shed, when pleading for me to my mother!—My heart, at least, has for once e∣lected a real friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Cecilia.
SP.P: I hope so, but the same facility with which I was exalted to that character, might expose you to much deceit and treachery.—You see I use the privilege you give me.

SP.SPEAKER: Isabella.
SP.P: Do so always, and assist me if you can, to root up my idle prejudices altogether, and to renounce, for ever, the exaggerated expressions and unnatural sentiments of that which you have convinced me is false SENSIBILITY.

DIV1.Q: The Story of Melanthon affords a striking Les∣son on the Value of Time, which was, that whenever he made an appointment, he al∣ways expected not only the Hour, but the Minute, should be fixed; that the Day might not run out in the Idleness of Suspence. JOHNSON.

LIST.HEAD: CHARACTERS.
LIST.ITEM: Mrs. Cecil, Governess to the Miss Mildmays.
Ruth Saunders, A Poor Woman. Sally.

DIV2.HEAD: THE LITTLE TRIFLER.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE a Room with Book-cases, Globes, a Harpsichord, &c.
Enter Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, and Eudocia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I FEEL so chearful this fine morning, that I hope I shall get through my employments comfortably before we go for our ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Yes, and the sun is so enlivening, we shall enjoy our air∣ing of all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: To do that, you must all of you perform your tasks well.—As to Miss Mildmay, I need not remind her, she is always ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: You are always too good to me, my dear governess.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Not better than you deserve, Sophia, we are all ready to allow that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, yes, the praise of candour and affection be∣longs to you equally.—But we lose time.—Where is Miss Laura?—Idling, I dare say. I never shall succeed in my endeavours to teach that child the value of those minutes she wastes so abominably!—Nothing but a concurrence of circumstances will make her aware of the necessity there is, if we would go through our duties properly, of being punctual. 'Tis past nine, she must know it, and yet she is not here.—Do, Miss Eudocia, ring the bell. (Eudocia rings the bell, they draw a small table, and sit down to work.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Sally, pray tell Miss Laura 'tis past nine; I want her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Don't you think Sal∣ly a very good girl ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, I do indeed. Your mama has had her in her ser∣vice six years, all that time she has behaved unexceptionably. She was very young when she came hither, and had before been tole∣rably educated; therefore I do not object to your talking to her some∣times, though I strictly forbid your doing so to the other servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P:
We are perfectly con∣vinced of the propriety of that. Indeed I cannot conceive how any one can wish it, their language is
so unpleasant; and can one expect either pleasure or improvement from those who have had no edu∣cation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Those must have a very bad taste who do.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, is it nine o'clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, a full quarter after; what have you been doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Why ma'am, I asked after breakfast what it was o'clock, and they said it wanted a quarter of nine, so I thought I would set one of my drawers in order, but I did not begin directly, and I fancy that made me so late.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
Yes, most likely—your drawers generally require more than a quarter of an hour to set them to rights, and even of that quarter it seems you trifled a∣way
part. If you would but con∣sider whether it is possible to do what you undertake in the time you can spare to it, you would not be so often behind your time.—And how have you left your cloaths now?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh ma'am, when Sally called me, I push'd them all into the drawer as well as I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: (laughing.) Push'd them—yes, your things are generally pretty well push'd, as you call it!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: You have nothing to do with that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Come, come, leave off talking, and get to work—but remember I will have your drawer set to rights before you go out.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh I shall have plen∣ty of time to do that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
Aye!—that is exact∣ly
your way!—You always have plenty of time in idea, and none in reality; of course you are always unpunctual.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: If I am, it is not a great fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Fye Laura!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Is it not a great fault?—There I differ from you.—It leads to very unpleasant conse∣quences at least—often to very bad ones. In the first place, you trifle away a great deal of time: for in∣stance, your sisters have been at work some minutes; of course their tasks will be done sooner, and they will have the more time for other employments.—It is a chance if you are ready to go out with your mama: you have all your work to do; to read French, and to put your drawers in order.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well, all that is my lss▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Your accent and manner are a little impertinent, but I will pass that over, as I wish if possible, to convince you by reasoning.—Suppose then, when you are older, you should appoint a friend to meet you at any place, and because you forget, or over stay your time, she is disappointed and has her trouble for nothing—That will be her loss, I think!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes; but it would not be of much consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: You are very slow to be convinced!—Suppose her business is of consequence, and can∣not be delayed!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh but I should know that, and should be sure to be there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
Very well! if you can all at once break thro' a set∣tled habit, you have greater com∣mand
of yourself than I give you credit for.—You will see, and we shall learn, if you do not regret the many moments you have lost in idle trifling.—When do you mean to begin work?
SP.STAGE: (Laura takes several pieces of work out of her bag.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Why do you take out so much at once? you cannot do it all!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Which should I do ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: This is what you left on Saturday, on promise to do it to-day; and this is your task for this morning, which I will have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But there is so much!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Not so much as I have given your sisters!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But they are older!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
Yes, and somewhat
more industrious: there is not too much for you; so no more dispu∣ting, but begin.
SP.STAGE: (Laura sits down by Sophia. Af∣ter a short pause, she yawns; then leans on Sophia's chair, and whispers to her, Sophia makes no answer.)

SP.SPEAKER: Laura,
SP.P: (in a low voice.) Now pray do, Sophia!—You cannot think how much I shall be obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Have done, Laura!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Hush, don't speak so loud!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I do not chuse to whis∣per!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Pray what are you doing, Miss Laura? Attend to your work, I beg of you; you are like all idle people, fond of distur∣bing others.

STAGE.HI: (A short pause, during which they work. When Mrs. Cecil is not observing her, Laura wraps her work round her thread pa∣pers like a doll, and jogs Eudo∣cia.)

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Eudocia, look, look, I say, is not it droll?

STAGE.HI: (Eudocia looks up: tries to a laugh, but cannot. Mrs. Ce∣cil looks towards them. Laura snatches up her work.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: How now, young ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: My stars, Laura, you are so ridiculous, you make me laugh!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: (laughing.) I!—'Twas the thread papers!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Oh to be sure! Have done, I charge you.—(Another pause, then Laura whispers Sophia.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Do pray be quiet, Lau∣ra, you are very teazing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: What is all this about?—Miss Mildmay, what is she saying?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Asking me, ma'am, to tell her something I have refused to let her know twenty times al∣ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: She is very imper∣tinent.—I shall remove you, Miss Laura, if you torment your sister so.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Because it is so cross, ma'am, it cannot be a secret, only she chuses to make it one on purpose to teaze me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: That is very like∣ly—But no more of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, it's some∣thing so very odd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Hold your peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: What does she want to know, Sophia?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I want to know what—▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: I insist on your not speaking.—You have all the faults of a Trifler, curious, imper∣tinent, chattering.—I wish you could see how disagreeable you make yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Here comes mama.

DIV2.STAGE: (They rise.—The girls run and em∣brace their mother.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Sit still Mrs. Cecil.—My dear girls, how are you?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Quite well, mama, thank ye—are you well?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Yes; tho' a little late this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: You sat late last night, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Yes, the plea∣sure of seeing my son detained me later than usual.—How do your pupils behave, Mrs. Cecil?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Vastly well, ma'am except a little—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Laura, I sup∣pose—you are conscious, I see!—I too have a complaint to make.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Dear mama!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Yes, I have indeed, but sit down to your works.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Should I sit, mama while you are speaking to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: No, my dear, I shall excuse as much of your work as you would have done in the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: As much as she might have done, my dear Mrs. Cecil; what she would have done is, I fancy, rather doubtful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, ma'am.

DIV2.P:
You look a little alarm'd, Lau∣ra, but I am not very angry with
you, since I believe your fault pro∣ceeded as usual from want of thought.—Yesterday, at church my dear, you behaved very ill.—In the first place, while we stood up, I saw your eyes wandering all over the church: in the next place, while we were sitting, you whis∣per'd to Eudocia, jogged her el∣bow, and tried to make her laugh.—Now, my dear, I beg you to consider how very improper all this is.—Do you know for what pur∣pose we go to church?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes, mama, surely, to pray to God.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Well then, can you think such behaviour proper?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But it was not during the prayers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
True, but part was during the psalms, which are intended as immediate addresses to
our Creator, of both praise and prayer; therefore we stand to show our reverence and attention.—When we were sitting it was to hear the lessons read; that is, selected parts of the holy scripture, the immediate word of God, and the the rule by which we are to direct our life.—Even if the service had not been begun, or had been ended, to talk and laugh would have been highly improper.—It unfits the mind for serious duties, and implies a lightness and thoughtlessness, which ought not to be indulged or allowed in a place sacred to our maker.—Our Saviour showed his disapprobation of any thing which might disturb the tranquillity and decency of the holy place, by driv∣ing from the Temple (the place of worship) at Jerusalem those whom human laws allowed to transact
business there, saying, "It is writ∣ten, my house shall be called the house of prayer, but ye have made it a den of thieves."—I am sure if you were in the President's presence, you would not be so ill-bred as to laugh and whisper, when he was speaking to you, or allowing a∣nother to do so; how much less then, when God speaks to you by his scriptures, ought you to behave irreverently?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I am fully convinced, mama, I am much obliged to you for taking the trouble of instruct∣ing me▪ and, I assure you, I will never behave so aga.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I thank you also, mama, for I never saw this matter so clearly before.—I knew it was wrong to talk at church, but some∣times I have forgotten it; now I think nothing will ever tempt me to do so again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: I am always happy, my children, to be of service to you, and while I see you will∣ing to be convinced and to amend, I am over paid for any trouble I can be at in instructing yo.—Laura, return to your work.—At one o'clock, you will all be ready to go out; I shall not wait a min∣ute for any-body, unless Mrs. Ce∣cil can give me a good reason for the delay. Sophia, your brother will take you in his phaeon; our cold provisions are all packed up.—I hope to hear a good account of you all: remember, that if you would enjoy the ride, and the ight of the gardens we are to visit, you must behave well.—Good-bye.—Mrs. Cecil, a good morning to you.—I hope you will like our ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
Yes, ma'am, I
have no doubt of it; a good morn∣ing to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Now, Mrs. Cecil, how much will you allow me, to leave of my work?

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: That is Laura's first concern?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: So it would be yours, if you had as much to do as I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I had as much at first.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But mama has not been talking to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: No, because I behav∣ed better yesterday than you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Eudocia, when my mother is satisfied with the atone∣ment for a fault, it does not be∣come us to mention it reproachful∣ly.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
Thank ye, Sophia, you seldom take my part, and Eudocia
deserves a good lecture this time—however!

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Then you think I do not often deserve one?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: However that may be, you certainly de now.—Have done disputing, Eudocia, that is your principal fault; you have been wrong all the way now you had, as your sister observed, no right, nor was it kind, to resume a subject your mama had done with; and to answer so sharply and so of∣ten, shews an inclination to quar∣rel, very unpleasant and improper.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia,
SP.P: (after a short pause.) It is very true, I have been wrong. Laura, I beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh my dear, how good you are!—I am not angry!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: How sweetly was that said!—How amiable is candour!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, I am pleased with Eudocia!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
