SP.P: Well, nothing affects me like hearing any one say in that honest way, "I was wrong, I beg your pardon."—I never can help crying, and I feel so sorry and so humble, and so pleased with them—But in spite of all that, I never can prevail on myself to ask par∣don; I feel so ashamed, and so afraid of being laughed at!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
That is false shame.—No shame is just, but the shame of a bad or improper action; and as to being laughed at, the person who can laugh at another for doing as she ought, must be un∣able to taste the sweetness of vir∣tue, and the exaltation of humility.—But go on with your work, Laura: I shall allow you to leave off, when you have done so much,
(measuring her work.)—You have been sadly idle. Eudocia, you may now read: bring that little book of manuscripts your mama gave you on Saturday.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P:
Yes, ma'am.—(She sits down by Mrs. Cecil; takes a small book, and reads.) "Come ye who love to see what is beautiful—come who wish to enjoy what is sublime—come and I will di∣rect your eyes to the bright Moon, which rides triumphantly on the bosom of heaven. Is she not beautiful, when breaking thro' the black clouds which surround her, she diffuses splendour around!—Is she not sublime when sinking be∣neath the able veil, she just tinges with lucid silver its unequal edges!—Again she swells above the hea∣vy vapour, and shines in perfect beauty. So rises from the false
imputations of malicious slander, the undiminished lustre of true vir∣tue. The machinations of evil men, the unavoidable concurrence of accident, may a while overspread the beauty of a good name with heavy clouds, but its splendour shall return, and its enemies shall fly be∣fore it like the broken and disjoint∣ed track, which flies from the face of the Moon.—Comfort your∣selves, then, ye sons of men: des∣pair not, because darkness, or e∣ven the shadow of death, surrounds you.—Time shall make manifest the beauty of goodness, and its soft lustre shall diffuse a sweet and calm satisfaction into the bosoms of all who believed it."

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: That is very pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
The imitation of Mrs. Barbauld's hymn, "Come,
and I will shew you what is beauti∣ful"—at the begining of this little piece, is obvious; but though in∣ferior to that charming production, it is not without merit.—Read one more, Miss Eudocia.

DIV2.P:
How swiftly does imagination wing her flight!—Ere an instant has rolled over our head she conveys us to the most distant quarter of the globe; she represents to our mind the most remote events!—Time and dist∣ance fade before her, and her way is as unmarked as it is swift. We set out with one idea, and without being sensible of the pro∣gressive change, we find ourselves meditating another.—Imagination then is like a voyager who, em∣barking on an immense river, is lul∣led by the found of the rippling water into a soft repose: he awake
and finds himself in another coun∣try▪ the trees, the flowers, the whole face of nature is chang∣ed: perhaps he has in his slumber passed from the most gloomy scenes to the most enlivened, but he shud∣ders in reflecting that he has prob∣ably also passed a tremendous fall or a lurking quicksand! In like man∣ner the mind, wrapt in contempla∣tion, may perhaps touch on the confines of some forbidden idea, some false principle, or scheme of gu.—Happy those who pass them without harm; who do not indulge in such imaginations, but, if they perceive them, start aside, and direct their course to a more desirable climate."

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
Very well—that is sufficient.—Now, Miss Laura, bring me your Telemachus. Maintenant, Ma∣demoiselle
Laura, apportez moi∣ore Telemaque.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Laura. Yes, ma'am. Oui, Madame.—(She rises, loo in the book-case, then says) Oh dear, it is not here, 'tis upstairs!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: How came it up stairs?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Mama desired to hear me read while she dress'd yesterday and afterwards I took the book into my own room, and forgot to bring it down.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Well, make haste and fetch it; there is so much time lost!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh I shall be back in a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: What a careless child!

STAGE.HI: (Laura returns with the book; se sits down and reads.)

SP.P: "Narbal me regardoit avec étonnement, et il crut appercevoi en moi je ne scai quoi de hureux qui vient des dons du Ciel, et qui n'est point dans le commun des hommes: il etoit naturellement sincère et genereux; il fut touché de mon malheur, et me prla avec ne confiance, que les Dieux lui in∣spirèrent pour me sauver d'un grand peril, &c. &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: That is well read; now Miss Mildmay you will trans∣late it.
SP.STAGE: (Laura returns to her work; So∣phia takes her book.)
SP.P:
"Narbal regarded me with astonishment, and believed he per∣ceived in me a certain expression of goodness, which is the gift of Heaven, and is not common among men. He was naturally sincere and generous; he was touched
with my misfortunes, and he spoke to me with a confidence which the Gods inspired, to save me from imminent danger.—Telemachus, said he to me, I neither do nor can doubt that which you tell me. The softness and virtue painted on your countenance will not suffer me to supect you; I even feel that the Gods whom I have always served love you, and decree that I shall regard you as my son. I will give you salutary conels, and in return I only demand that you shall be secret.—Fear not, said I to him, that I shall find any difficul∣ty in concealing those things which you confide to me. Though young, I am old in the habit of never re∣vealing my own secrets, and still less the secrets of others. How have you been able, said he, in such extreme youth, to accustom your∣self
to secrecy: I shall be delight∣ed to know by what means you have acquired that quality, which is the foundation of the wisest con∣duct, and without which all tal∣ents are useless? When Ulysses, I replied, departed for the siege of Troy, he took me on his knees, holding me in his arms, (as I have been told) and after he had kissed me tenderly, he used these words, tho' I could not understand them. Oh! my son, may the Gods never suffer me to see thee again; rather let the fatal scissars cut the thread of thy days ere it be half formed, as the reaper cuts down with his sickle a tender flower as it be∣gins to open; may my enemies dash thee in pieces before the eyes of thy mother and myself, if thou doomed one day to be corrupt∣ed and to abandon virtue!—Oh'
my friends, continued he, I leave to you a son so dear: take care of his infancy. If you love me, banish from him pernicious flatter∣ry; teach him how to conquer his passions, that he may be like a tender plant which men often bend in order to make it grow upright: above all, forget nothing which may render him just; benevolent, sincere, and faithful in keeping a secret: whoever is capable of ly∣ing, does not deserve to live; and whoever knows not how to be si∣lent, is unworthy to govern. I re∣peat these words exactly; because care was taken to recount them to me frequently, and that they sunk into the bottom of my heart."

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Very well rendered indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P:
This is a charming passage!—One sees in the first
part of it, how agreable to all men is a candid open countenance, which can only be preserved by retaining Truth in the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, and the latter part is an excellent lesson.—When you are disposed to teaze your sis∣ters out of a secret, Laura, recol∣lect this passage, and learn the ne∣cessity of a prudent reserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But Ulysses said, who∣ever could not be silent was unworthy to govern, my sisters are not going to govern.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
I never saw a young lady more ingenious at finding objections. These words were addressed to a young prince, therefore the word govern is used, but secrecy is a quality equally necessary in all situations, besides, you may probably some time or other govern a family, though not a
kingdom, and believe me, you would find yourself very ill qualified to do that if you told your servants, your neighbours, and whoever would hear you, all the concerns of your houshold, and every thing which came to your knowledge.—Have you done work, young la∣dies?—'Tis past twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: And I.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I have a little bit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: You must have been very idle, for I gave you very little.—You must dress, and set your drawer in order, so make haste.
SP.STAGE: (Sophia and Eudocia rise, fold their work and put it away.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
Laura, what's the reason your poor squirrel has
not been cleaned and fed?—I heard him very restless, looked at him, and found he had nothing to eat or drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh dear, mama, on Saturday I had not time, yesterday I could not do it, and this morning, before breakfast, I had so much to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: I told you then not to trifle so much time away, in puttig on your cloaths. In the midst of dresing, you took a fancy of reading two old letters, which you found in one of your drawers, then in spite of my re∣monstrances you entirely new dressed your doll, and had only time to take half a turn in the garden, though your sisters and I walked a considerable time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
That is always the way. You will take improper
times to do things. You have no regularity, no idea how much time it will take to accomplish such and such things.—When you had the squirrel, it was on promise to take care of it yourself; you shall not go out till he is fed.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But, mama, I have not quite done work, I must put my drawer in order, and dress myself, I shall not be ready.—Mayn't Sally clean my squirrel's cage?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: No, she shall not.—'Tis your own fault if you are not ready, and I will not in∣dulge you in such idle ways.—Let me hear what you have done since breakfast?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
Mama, I began put∣ting my drawer to rights, which I had not time to finish: I have
read French, and hemmed all this muslin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: And you, Eu∣docia.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Mama, I made part of a paper-box, and wrote my jour∣nal in my pocket-book, before school hour; and since I have read and worked this pattern of my frock.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: There, Laura, and all that in exactly the same time you have had?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Indeed, mama, I will manage better another time!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Very well; at present however, you must do all you have to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Mrs. Cecil, shall we dress?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
I am dressed, therefore, Mrs. Cecil, I will take
care that Laura finishes her em∣ployments while you dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Thanks to you, ma

SP.SPEAKER: Laura▪
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Cecil, ex∣cuse me this bit of work!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: No, Mrs. Ce∣cil, I beg you will not!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Indeed, ma'am, I am not at all disposed to do so, un∣less you should desire it.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, and Eudocia, go out.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Mama, I have done work.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Very well; go then, and do all you have under∣taken, and if you are ready, you shall go with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Mama, tell me what's o'clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Half past twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: And you go at one.—Well I think, I shall be ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: I think you will not.

DIV2.HEAD: THE LITTLE TRIFLER.
PART II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Mildmay, meeting Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, and Eudocia.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay,
SP.P: WELL, Mrs. Cecil, are you ready? Where's Laura?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: Not ready, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Then I shall not wait; she deserves to be left behind, and 'tis now ten minutes past one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Mama, she will be rea∣dy in five minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
No matter, it already past the time I had fix∣ed;
we are to be at home by five, and we shall have barely time to see the gardens.—It is her own fault: let us go.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Oh I am very sorry indeed Laura will not go!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Ma'am, Miss Laura begs you will be good enough to wait ten minutes; she will be dress∣ed in that time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: No, I will not▪ I have said I will not, and she knows I always keep my word. Come, Mrs. Cecil, come children. Sadly, tell Laura to confine her∣self to this room and the garden while we are gone; I will not have her running about among the servants.—Lay the cloth for her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
I am very sorry for poor
Miss Laura, she will be so vexed!—But she is always past her time.—To-day, truly, she has been chattering to me instead of dressing, though she knew her mama would not wait. "Oh I have plenty of time, it is not near one!"—that is her way.—Oh here she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Sally, do you know where my gloves are?—I am rea∣dy now!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Ah miss!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What?—Bless me!—Sure mama is not gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Indeed, miss, I am sorry to say she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: You jest, I am sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
No, truly miss, I should not take that liberty. Your mama would not wait a minute longer; both Miss Mildmay and Miss Eudocia tried to prevail on
her, but she said you knew she never broke her word;

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: (with tears in her eyes.) You may go Sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Miss, your mama order∣ed me to tell you, she desired you to to stay in this room.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Very well.
SP.STAGE: (Sally goes out. Laura draws a chair, throws herself into it: rises again, and walks impatient∣ly about the room.)

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
It is too bad, I declare!—To go without me; and to order me to stay in this room.—What is the reason of that, I wonder.—And George is gone with them. He goes away to-morrow.—This last day, which I thought to have spent so pleasantly, to be so disap∣pointed.—'Tis very cross in mama, I am sure.—(She wipes her eyes.) I am always to blame: "Laura did this, Laura did that, Laura
is always wrong.—(She pauses.) After all, I certainly might have been ready.—How did I dare say, mama was cross.—What! mama, who is always so kind, so indul∣gent, so equal in her sweetness of temper!—It was very wrong in me.—Dear mama, though you can∣not hear me, I wish to ask your pardon.—Well, what shall I do while they are gone?—How te∣dious the time is.—(A pause.) Lord bless me, I wish I might walk in the garden.—Perhaps mama said I might: I will inquire—(She goes to the door, and calls) Sally!—Sally!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Did you call, miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes.—Did mama say I might walk in the garden?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
Yes, miss; I thought I had told you, this room and the garden.—My mistress said, you
should not run about among the servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh that was the rea∣son!—I am glad I know that.—Apropos, I wish I could find out this mighty secret of Sophia's.—Sally do you know it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: What, miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
Why, I'll tell you. About a month ago, mama gave Sophia two guineas, and told her to buy whatever she liked best with it. She gave one to Eudocia and one to me. Eudocia bought a small writing desk; and I bought a squirrel's cage, and some flower seeds for my garden: but Sophia said she would wait awhile and consider before she bought. Well, yesterday it came into my head that she had not bought any thing; and I asked her what she should purchase with her two guineas.—
She coloured a little, and said, "Oh something I shall like."—Mrs. Cecil smiled, and I have never been able to get a more direct an∣swer from Sophia.—Now, Sally, do you know what she means to buy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Dear Miss, is it likely I should know?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: No, but you might nevertheless.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: And if I did, what ad∣vantage would it be to you to be told?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh then you do know!—Ah ha!—Come, my dear Sally, tell me, I pray you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: I did not say I knew▪ miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, but I am sure of it.—Pray tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
ye miss!—Consider, if I did know, your sister must
have told me in confidence; and do you think I would betray her?—Oh no, my good mistress has taught me better!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well, you know, how∣ever; so she has determined on something, that is one step gained—I shall soon guess what!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: But, Miss Laura, who told you I knew?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Who?—yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: I!—that I could not!—I said if, but it was only sup∣posing!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What then you don't know!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: (laughing) That you should really fancy Miss Mildmay had told me!—Surely she would have told you first!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: No, no, she would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Why, miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Because she thinks I should tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Then you believe she thinks I would not?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I suppose so!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: You me a great compliment, miss; which I will try to deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well, I cannot tell whether you know or not, but I have not you all.—Mrs. Ce∣cil and Sophia have risen half an hour earlier than common this last fortnight, and I wish I knew what for; I never could find out how they had employed them∣selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Well, miss, if I might venture to speak, I should say it was not worth taking so much trouble to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: If I think it is, that's enough.—I do not ask your ad∣vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: You may go.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Let me consider —What can Sophia warn to pur∣chase—books has plenty, and mama is always buying fo.—A box of colours.—She one.—New musick—perhaps—but why make a secret of it!—Ah!—a locket of mama's hair! That must be it!—I dare say it is very pretty, and she means to surprise us with it, I suppose!—But then what have Mrs. Cecil and Sophia been doing in the morning?—Oh, perhaps, they are painting a device for it.—Yes, yes, that is it!

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Miss, there is a woman below stairs, in great distress; she is very poor, and she begs to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well shew her up; I will speak to her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Yes, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What shall I be able to do for her, I have but half a crown, but I can speak to mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: That is Miss Laura.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Come in good woman.
SP.STAGE: (Sally goes out.—Ruth curtsies, and comes a little forward.)

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What can I do for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: Miss I came to beg some relief from my lady, but your ser∣vants tell me she is not at home, so I made bold to ask leave to speak to you, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Very well; what can I do to serve you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P:
Alas aday, my young
lady, I am grievous poor; I am a widow, with three children, the eldest of 'em is out at service, but the two little ones are too young to go out: my old mother lives with us; she is helpless, and you may think, miss, I find it hard to keep so many with the work of my own hands.—In the summer, I work in the fields: in the win∣ter, I spin; and my children help me as well as they can. For two years, that my husband has been dead, we have done pretty well, 'till this last winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What happened then?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P:
Alas, miss! in the au∣tumn, I was so unhappy as to get an ague, which hindered my working a great deal; my children could do but little; they began to get dirty and ragged; it ut me to the heart to see them so,
and not be able to help them!—To complete my misfortune, a dog got into my little garden, and killed my two hens, whose eggs used to furnish us with a sure penny. Things went from bad to worse; I was fain to run in debt to my landlord, and tho' now the summer is coming on, and I am better, I hope I should be able to pay him; the cruel man de∣clares he will seize for rent to-mor∣row morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What is seizing for ent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: Ah, miss! he will take all our little cloaths and furniture, and the very beds we lye on, my poor old mother's and all, to sell them, and pay himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Can he be so cruel!—Is he poor?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P:
No, miss, he has four
hundred pounds a year, and only himself and his wife to keep.—What will become of my poor children, and my mother!—At seventy years old; must she be turned out to starve?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: (eagerly.) No, o, she shall not—be easy—I promise you she shall not.—Poor, good woman, how I pity you—but what do you owe this unfeeling wretch?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: Oh, good young lady, a great deal!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But how much?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: Thirty shillings, for half a year's rent.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, how unfortunate I am!—If I had not spent my guinea, I should have had almost enough; and perhaps he would have waited awhile.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P:
Ah, miss, you are
very good!—but don't think I came here to beg my lady to pay for me; no, indeed, miss I only thought if she would speak to my landlord, he would may-be wait a little; and indeed I hope I shall pay him every farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I am sure mama will do that and perhaps more. I will speak to her for you good woman; make yourself easy, I will do all I can for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P:
Thank you a thousand times, good young lady; we shall all pray for, and bless you. I have often seen your two sisters walking with Madam Cecil, and I have thought when Miss Mild∣may looked so kindly on my poor little girls, while they opened the gate for her, and said with her sweet voice, "Poor children, there's a penny for you."—I have
thought if she did but know how wretched we were, she would speak to my lady for us; but I had not the heart to tell her, 'till now; things getting so bad, I thought I would try at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: You did very right.—Call again at six o'clock; I will see you, and before that I will speak to mama, you may depend on it.—In the mean time, I will give you this half crown; I have no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: No, miss, I thank you, I will not rob you; you will do all for me in speaking to your ma∣ma.—She is so good, she deserves to have good children, and she is rewarded!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But I insist on your ta∣king this money; I wish it was more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: It does not become me to refuse your favors.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Take it, buy something with it for your mother.—Good woman, I love you for being so kind to her! (She calls) Sally!

DIV2.P: Take this good woman with you, and give her something to eat: mama will not object to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: No, miss, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: And when she comes again, let me know.—A good day to you.—Oh, tell me your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: Ruth Saunders, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Very well, I shall re∣member.

SP.SPEAKER: Ruth.
SP.P: Your servant, miss, a thousand thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well, I shall not re∣gret being left at home, since it has been the cause of my seeing this poor woman.

DIV2.P: Do you know that woman, Sally?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Yes, miss, I have seen her often; she is very poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: So I hear—but why I wonder did she never come hither before?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Ah, miss! 'tis very hard to beg; people who have been u∣sed to keep themselves by their own industry, are ashamed and afraid to ask relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Ashamed, perhaps; but why afraid?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Because, miss, so many gentlefolks are cross and hard∣hearted; and one says—"Where did you learn all that history," and another says, "Ah, a sad sto∣ry, if it is true!"

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But that is abominable if we don't chuse to give, we need not insult the poor creature who begs from us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Very true, miss, but too many don't think of that; they forget that a beggar has any feel∣ing. I once saw a poor man col∣our like scarlet, and his eyes spar∣kle with anger, at a gentleman, who said he was an impostor; but, poor wretch, he recollected him∣self, put his hand on his bosom, sighed and passed on.—I gave him a trifle; he bowed, and I saw the tears in his eyes; he did not speak.—Poor creature, truly he was cut to the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: You are a good girl, Sally—but tell me what you know of this poor woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
Why, miss, she lives in a little cottage just at the end of the village, and keeps it very neat when she is well; she has two pretty children, and her mother (a good old woman) lives with her▪
the old woman is lame, but has all her senses, and when dame Saun∣ders was so ill, the poor old woman used to cry, and the little girls, thinking to comfort her, said, "Don't cry grandmother, I will feed you, and put on your clean cap for you."

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Poor little dears!—how did you know this, Sally?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Oh I heard hem one day, miss; when I was walking by the house, I saw the poor wo∣man standing at the door; she look'd sickly, so I asked her a few questions, and found the ague was off that day, and she had crept to the door for a little air.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: And when was this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: About a month ago, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: And why did you not tll mama?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
I did, miss, and my
mistress ordered the cook to send her some broth twice or three times, and Miss Sophia sent her a shilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I never heard of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: No, miss, because Miss Sophia never tells the good she does.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: That is right, but I wonder I don't hear of it.—Indeed I never see any poor people; they don't come here, I fancy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: No, miss, your gover∣ness and sisters find them out when they walk of a morning before breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: That may be, for I don't know how, I seldom have time to walk of a morning. Well, I will walk in the garden, and then learn my grammar-task; then, for once, I shall be beforehand.—Af∣terwards I will dine.—You will lay the cloth, Sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Yes, miss.

DIV2.P: Miss Laura is very good; she has an excellent heart, but she is so light-headed and careless; 'tis a great pity, and I hope she will break herself of it in time; no doubt she will, for she has very good sense. Well, this room will do now.

DIV2.HEAD: THE LITTLE TRIFLER.
PART III.

P.HI: Mrs. Mildmay, Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, Eudocia, taking off their Cloaks and Hats, which they give to Sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: WHERE is Laura, Sally?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Ma'am, she is walking in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Has she dined

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Well, call her hither directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: We have had a delightful day indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Very charming; and our little hasty dinner I enjoyed wonderfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: I never ate with better appetite in my life, than in the snug little cottage George found out for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I only wished for Laura.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: That indeed was only wanting to make our party com∣plete.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, mama, are you returned; I did not expect you quite so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: 'Tis past ; but, Laura, your brother has not ordered his phaeton from the door, having prevailed on me to suffer you to take a little ride with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: And ma ▪ mama?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: if you have behaved well we have been goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes indeed, mama, I have only been in this room and the garden, and I have learned my grammar-task.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Well, go then.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes, mama, thank you! thank you!—
SP.STAGE: (She runs a few steps; then re∣turns, and whispers Sophia.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Pshaw, nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Aye, but I have indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Come, come, Laura, get your hat, and be gone; your brother waits.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes, mama—Good bye—Good bye, Mrs. Cecil, Sophia, Eudocia, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: What did she say to you, Sophia?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: she had discov∣ered my ma.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: What does she mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: You know, mama, how I have disposed of the two guineas you were so good as to give me▪ and Laura has been teazing me since yesterday to know what I mean to buy: I refused to tell her, and she fancies she has guess'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Silly child, how light her head is!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: But perhaps she really knows.—She may have learned from Sally, who bought my mate∣rials, and even assisted in the work.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: No, I believe Sal∣ly is perfectly faithful.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: I believe so too.—We will ask her presently, if Laura has been questioning her.—But why did you so much object to Laura's knowing it, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Because mama, Laura can no more keep a , than she can let any one else keep it in peace, and I know she would have told every-body she had met with; which, for many reasons, I wish'd to avoid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: It is very true, that those who are extremely cu∣rious, are generally unable to keep a secret, because it gratifies their self-importance, to shew that they know more than others, and be∣cause they hope to obtain new se∣crets, in return for those they tell: not considering, that a wise person will never place confidence in one who has abused the same trust from another.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
There is nothing, I think, on which young people ought to be more scrupulous than on the subject of Confidence.—Let
them not be over-fond of seeking a trust, which generally brings with it anxiety and care; but if by any accident, or any necessity, they find themselves in possession of a secret, they ought, with ex∣treme delicacy and caution, to preserve a trust so sacred.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
Most surely.—And the limits of Confidence are very strict.—It is not only what our friends say, prefaced by "I beg you will not tell this," which we ought to consider as confided to us. Every thing which we can suppose they would not wish re∣vealed, we ought to consider as told in confidence. Having once confi∣ded in a person, we do not say eve∣ry minute, "don't mention that."—We suppose their own prudence will teach them what ought to be kept secret; and every thing is told
in confidence which passes between friends, either relating to their situations, sentiments, or opinions; often, indeed, when referring to these circumstances in others.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Mama, I have heard people say, that we ought not to tell to one friend what another has told us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Certainly not. The person who confides in you may not have an equally good opinion of your friend, or circumstances may render it very improper to entrust her. You may not be able to judge of these circumstances; therefore you ought to be as reser∣ved to her as to the rest of the world: besides, she also might have a friend, to whom she might not scruple to tell the secret; that friend another, and so on without any bound.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I see that very clear∣ly.—But suppose I should, know the person who entrusts me is also very intimate with my friend, and loves her, might I not then talk about the affair with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
No, not with∣out leave from the person who en∣trusts you; if she chuses to tell this third person, she can; if not, you may be sure she has some reason against it. I lately read a story exactly in point.—When Gen. Monk projected the Restoration of Charles the IId. he maintained the strictest reserve on the subject, e∣ven to his friends.—He sent, how∣ever, for his brother, Dr. Monk, intending to confide his plan to him, and even giving him some hints respecting it.—When Dr. Monk arrived, while waiting for admis∣sion to the General, he entered in∣to
conversation with the General's Chaplain, in whom he knew he confided and talked with him on the plan.—When he was admitted to his brother, the General asked him if he had mentioned the subject to any one?—"To nobody," said the Doctor, "but to your Chap∣lain, whom I know you trust."—The General immediately changed countenance, dropped the discourse and soon after sent his brother a∣way; not chusing to trust a man who had talked on a subject of so much consequence to another, even tho' he would himself have trusted him Hun's History of England.. A proof of his wisdom; for surely Dr. Monk had evident∣ly shewed a want of delicacy in his sements, which rendered
him uit to have the care of a plan so important!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I admire the General's conduct extremely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P:
He was undoubt∣edly right. The faculty of keep∣ing a secret is highly necessary, yet rarely possessed. I made Laura remark that admirable pas∣sage in Telemachus to-day, because I remember the effect it had on myself.This is absolutely fact, of a child well known to the Author. Always fond of read∣ing, Telemachus fell early into my hands: I was not above eight years old when that passage struck me; I reflected on it, and it has in∣fluenced my conduct ever since. Such indeed has been the constant advantage I have derived from books.—My mother died ung:
and my father, encumbered with the care of a family, left us in great measure to educate ourselves. I was naturally very passionate, very idle, fond of beginning every thing, and ending nothing; but with a constant fondness for d∣ing, which in the end supplied to me the place of an instructor.—The same author, I have always loved so much, says in another placeHappy those who are amused by Instruction, and take delight in cultiva∣ting their minds by Science. Into what∣ever situation unkind Fortune may cast them, they carry always with them the means of conversation. And that fa∣tiguing Idleness, which devours so many, even in the midst of Pleasure, is un∣known to them who know how to em∣ploy themselves in reading.—Happy those who love to read!" "Heureux ceux qui se di∣vertissent
en s'intruisant, et qui se plaisent à cultiver leur ésprit par les sciences! En quelque endroit que la fortune ennemie les jette, ils portent ojours avec eux dequoi s'entretenir Et l'ennui, qui devore les au milieu même des delices, st inconnu à ceux qui savents' occuper par quelque lecture. Heureux ceux qui aiment à lire."—When I saw any very amiable character represented in my books, I considered whether I had, or wanted the qualities I admired so much. This was often a most unpleasant task, but I obliged my∣self to persevere in the inquiry; and having decided, tried to act accordingly.—When I read of any disagreeable character, and my heart told me I had its faults, I did not drive the conviction from me, but tried to correct myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: An admira∣ble example, and well worthy of being followed by those young people whose parents are either dead, or so engaged in business, as not to be able to attend to them: such young people would do well to observe the convictions of their own heart, and reason, and follow them, not refuse to listen to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I have often heard people say, it is of no use to read without reflection; but I never quite understood what was meant reflection, before. However, we are very happy in having a mother and governess so well able to instruct us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
Very true, you have great advantages; but, that does not render reflection less necessary to you: without it, our
precepts will be soon forgotten; and when you come to act for yourself, you will look round for those rules by which indeed you have been guided, but which you have neglected to implant in your heart; and missing them, you will no more know how to act in the world, than a man to find his way thro' a wood, which he had often seen at a distance, but whose particular situation he had neglect∣ed to mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Pray, ma'am, is Miss Laura here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: No, Sally, she is gone out with her brother.—Why; do you want her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
Ma'am, there is a poor woman below, who came while you were out: she saw Miss Lau∣ra,
who desired her to call again at six o'clock.—It is six o'clock now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Yes, but Laura has surely forgotten the appoint∣ment!—Idle child!—she will never learn to be punctual.—Where is the woman? I will see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: She is down stairs, ma'am. It is Dame Saunders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Indeed!—then perhaps—but she knw nothing of it: so Laura could not learn from her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: What, is it the woman for whom your gift was in∣tended!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Yes, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Sally, did Laura question you about the pur∣chase Miss Mildmay meant to make with her two guineas?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P:
Yes, ma'am, but I told her nothing; indeed she does not
know that I know any thing about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: That is right,—Come with me, Sophia; we will talk to the poor woman.
SP.STAGE: (Mrs. Mildmay, Sophia, and Sally go out)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: How shameful for Laura to have neglected an appoint∣ment; on which, probably, the peace and happiness of this poor woman depended!—And to have been surpassed by her servant in faithfulness and secresy!—All her faults proceed from carless∣ness, inattention, and want of punctuality.—Great vices, as well as great virtues, are rare; but it is those errors, which seem at first trifling, but which grow upon us by degrees, of which we ought principally to beware.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: But, Mrs. Cecil Laura is so young.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Cecil.
SP.P: Yes, she is young; but, with the advantages she has, she ought to know better: however, she has a good heart and understand∣ing▪ and, I hope, she will correct herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Oh yes, I hope so!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Oh, Mrs. Cecil, mama has rendered this poor woman so happy —She has been in the greatest distress about her rent: mama has given her money to pay it, and money to buy food and cloaths. I have desired her to wait, while Sally fetches down the box I design for her▪—Will you go with me, and give it to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Pray, sister, let me go also.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: My dear, I should be happy to do so; but I wish very much you would be kind enough to stay in this room. Laura will be at home in a few minutes; if she finds no one here, she will follow us; and mama is determined to punish her, for neglecting this poor woman, by leaving her in doubt whether she has been here or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Very well—I will call with you, then, to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P:
If you please; you o∣blige me extremely by this compli∣ance.—Only think, Laura had promised Ruth Saunders to repre∣sent her situation to mama, and to give her the answer at six o'clock.
She forgot all that!—but she gave her all the money she had; and Ruth said, behaved so kindly to her, as to make her quite happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: How capable she is of behaving well, if she does but think!

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: It is very true, in∣deed, that a habit of carelessness injures one extremely.—Laura this morning could not believe she should ever neglect an appointment of consequence.—Oh here she comes!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
So, Eudocia!—Where are mama and Mrs. Cecil; and Sophia, I don't see her either!—We have had a charming ride! My brother was very good to take me out, and he has been telling
me such delightful things about the ights in Philadelphia; he promises to ask mama to let me go next au∣tumn, and see them.—Shall you not wish me to go, Eudocia?

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: To be sure; why do you think I would not?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, because you looked so grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Did I look grave?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes, I think so.—Have you drank tea?

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: No: of course we should wait for my brother.
And for me, I hope you think I am of consequence enough to be waited for!

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: (smiling.) What do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Ah you y girl!—I know what you : 'tis true, mama did not think so this morn∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I assure you, we all wished for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh I don't doubt it at all. I shall be more punctual a∣nother time; for tho' I liked my ride, it did not make amends for losing so much pleasure.—And George must go to-morrow: he says it will be a month before he comes again.—How good he is; how I love him!

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: How we all love him—He is so attentive to us all!—Oh here comes Sophia.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Sophia, what are you come ?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Yes, I have been ex∣tremely lighted!

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Was he pleased?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Oh one so happy▪

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: So! so!—More secrets—Ah ha Sophia!—I have found out the last however!—Another time, I hope, you will trust me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Not the sooner because I find you curious, and prying in∣to what I wish to hide from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well, but my little Sophia, my dear sweet Sophia, don't be angry; you know I could not help guessing!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: You guess'd, did you?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Yes, I guess'd: well, Sophia, is it very beautiful?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Oh, very beautiful, if one did but know what you meant.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: You don't then, I sup∣pose?—Is the device handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: The device!—What nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What, then, I suppose you will not own you have pur∣chased a locket, with mama's hair?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: You have a fine guess, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: A true one, I fancy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: For once, you are en∣tirely mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: What can it be then!—Now, Sophia, do tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh do, pray do; in∣deed I will not tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I wish I had more rea∣son trust your however, 'tis no longer , so, if you wish it, I will tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh yes, yes, make haste, Sophia, make haste!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P:
You must know then, that, during the winter, I observed two pretty little girls, in the vil∣lage, almost without cloaths: I pitied them very much, and wished I could relieve them. I began by saving all I could out of my allow∣ance,
and had already some shil∣lings in advance, when mama gave me the two guineas: with her leave, I laid it out entirely in cloaths for the two little girls, and their mother, of whose distress I heard sad accounts.—Mrs. Cecil, Sally and I, have been hard at work in making these cloaths, whenever we could find time, and all is now finished.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: So, then, Sally knew!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: She would not tell!

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: What, you tried to make her?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I asked her—a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Fye, fye, Laura!—You must have supposed she knew in confidence, if she knew at all! On∣ly think what a shame, that your servant should know better how to act with respect to secresy than you.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Well, that is true; but, Sophia, who are these little girls?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Their mother's name is Ruth Saunders.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Ruth Saunders!—Oh goodness!—Is it six o'clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Six!—'tis almost se∣ven!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, where is mama!—Let me see her directly!—Where is Sally?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: What is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: Dear Laura.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia,
SP.P: (aside to her.) Hush—What's the matter, Laura?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, don't ask me!—I am ashamed of myself; tell me where is mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Mama is busy; you cannot see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, I must, I must!—Sally! Sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Oh, Eudocia, how I feel for her!

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I can hardly bear to see her so unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Mama has commanded silence!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Sally! Sally!—why don't you come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Miss!—Bless me, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Sally, has Ruth Saun∣ders been here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sally.
SP.P: Yes, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
Without seeing me!—What must she think of me!—It is almost dark too!—I shall not be able to see her to-night, and to-morrow!—Oh, poor creature, how unhappy she is.—But if I can
see mama, it may not be yet too late!—Dear Sophia, if you have any love for me, ask mama to let me see her!—I have something of great consequence to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear girl, it grieves me to refuse you, but mama has forbidden me to interrupt her.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: How can you be so unkind!—Indeed it is very cruel, and you seem not to feel for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Believe me, my dear, I feel for you very much.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Why then will you not intercede for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: I have told you alrea∣dy, that mama—

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh mama would hear me, if she knew—but how we lose time!—It will be too dark, and I shall be too late.—Eudocia will you ask mama to let me see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: I hear her coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh then I may still succeed!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Mildmay, and Mrs. Ce∣cil.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura,
SP.P: (running to Mrs. Mildmay.) Mama, dear mama, will you have the goodness to hear me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: What would you say?—Why this extreme a∣gitation?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
Oh mama, while you were gone, a poor woman came hither: she wanted relief from you; I saw her, I promised to in∣tercede for her, and give her the answer at six o'clock.—Her land∣lord has threaten'd to take all her goods for rent to-morrow morn∣ing. She hopes I shall prevail on you to plead for her to him. Dear∣est mama, will you grant me this
favour? Indeed she deserves your goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: How do you know that?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Because, mama, she told me all her story: she has been sick; she has two children, and an old mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: But, Laura, it is easy to say all that; nay, it may be true, and yet she may be idle and undeserving. You know I never exert myself but in favour of worthy objects. I have now no time to inquire, 'tis past seven, and very near dark; can I learn the truth of this story to-night?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: But, mama, to-morrow will be too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: Why then did you not tell me the story sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: I intended to do so, as soon as you came home, mama, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: But you forgot it!—Is it not so?—You chose the pleasure of a ride, rather than the gratifying these poor people:—Thus you have lost, from your carelessness and unpunctuality, an opportunity of doing a good action, of making a whole family happy, and of increasing my love for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, mama, I have been sadly to blame indeed, but I assure you this shall be the last time. Only hear me this once!—try what you can do for this poor woman; Sally knows her, nay Sophia knws her: inquire of them!—Punish me as you please, but do not punish her for my fault!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
Only imagine this poor creature's disappoinment when told you were not at home. Think of her distress: she had then lost her only hope!—See her re∣turning
to her cottage, where she had left her mother and children anxious for the success of her peti∣tion; hear her with tears say, "Ah my children, we must be ru∣ined; the person who promised us assistance has forgotten us!—She i gone out; she has not mentioned us to her mother, and to-morrow we shall be turned out to starve!"

SP.SPEAKER: Laura
SP.STAGE: Oh, mama, I implore you to save me from being the cause of this misery!—Indeed, I am cured for ever of my folly; I will never be trifling, inconsiderate, and unpunc∣tual again!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay,
SP.P:
Promises of amendment do not prove any thing, yet I must hope this lesson will reach your heart!—If I were as iconsiderate as you
all the sad consequences I have de∣scribed to you would be realized, and even all I can do will hardly efface from the mind of this poor woman the anguish she suffered when told you were gone out, and had not mentioned her to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Then, mama, you will be good enough to assist her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay
SP.P: Certainly I will; your breach of promise can be no reason why I should fail in my duty: but if. I had waited till I heard the story from you, it would really have been too late for me to do any thing in it, as I could not have learned all I wanted to know at this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Had you then heard it before?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
Yes; Sally, not finding you, came to me. I saw the poor woman; heard her
story, and having had eason before to believe it, I relieved her. So∣phia has given her a box of cloaths, and she is gone home perfectly hap∣py.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, mama, how good you are to every body!—Indeed, you may believe, I will profit by this lesson. I can never again run such a risk of making any one mis∣erable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Cecil.
SP.P: You must then break yourself of the habit of trif∣ling; for you see now, as I told you this morning, it cannot be dismissed at once, whenever it is of consequence it should be!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P:
Oh, it is true, indeed!—even, at least, when I came home if I had not trifled away the time, by asking Sophia impertinent ques∣tions, I should have found it less impossible to serve this poor wo∣man!
—dear Sophia, I will never teaze you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia.
SP.P: Believe me, it hurt me extremely, to keep the truth from you, when I saw you so distressed; but mama had commanded me not to tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eudocia.
SP.P: As to me, I was on the point of telling.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Mama, do you forgive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P:
I forgive you, hoping you will correct yourself, and that you now see the fault, you thought so trifling, is really of se∣rious consequence: but altho' I am no longer displeased, I shall inflict a punishment in addition to that which you have already suffered. I shall not permit you to have any share in the farther assistance we mean to give this poor woman; nor to call on her with your sisters
for a full fortnight; if, in that time, I see any instance of unpunc∣tuality in your conduct, I shall ex∣tend the time as long as I think proper.—So you will lose the plea∣sure of seeing her happiness, and the joy of her old mother and chil∣dren, for the gift Sophia has made them!

SP.SPEAKER: Laura.
SP.P: Oh, mama, this is in∣deed a punishment—but I deserve it!—However, I hope—I am sure I shall see her at the end of the fortnight!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mildmay.
SP.P: I hope you will.—But 'tis late.—Let us go down stairs to tea.—And let this occurrence teach us all never to forget our promise,, or let any gra∣tification tempt us to neglect our positive engagements.

FIGURE.HEAD: Little Country Visitor. Laura's Visit to the Young Montforts.

Q.L: Accomplishments by Heaven were first design'd
Less to adorn than to amend the mind.

LIST.HEAD: CHARACTERS.
LIST.ITEM: Maria, —A young woman under Mrs. Montfort's care.

DIV2.HEAD: THE Little Country Visitor.
DIV2.STAGE: Mrs. Montfort and Maria, at work.—Matilda and Harriot at a win∣dow; one dressing a doll, the other playing with a bandalore.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: HARRIOT, don't you think my doll looks very pretty in this bon∣net?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Yes; I wish you would make me such a one.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, to be sure!—No indeed!—Why don't you make yourself one?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: But I don't know how.—Well, if you won't, Maria will; won't you Maria?

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: What, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Make my doll a bon∣net, like Matilda's?

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: —Perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Oh, only perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: You know, Miss Har∣riot, it must depend on whether you behave properly, and whether your mama chuses it to be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Oh, but I will behave properly, and then mama will chuse it to be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: We shall see that.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I shall make my doll so many things this summer; we shall have so much time in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Not so much time truly!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: But we shall!—The days will be very long, and we shall get up early.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Yes, but then we shall run in the garden, and plant flowers, and that will take up our time.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: How shall we plant flowers?—We don't know how, nor when to water them.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Oh, James will tell us.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Well, I wish Miss Rosetta would come. I suppose she is pretty stupid!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Oh, and so awkward!—I dare say she hangs down her head, and won't speak, like those little girls we saw when we were in Worcester.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P:
Oh dear!—How droll they used to be. They used to curtsey, just so, (mimicking)
and say, yes, miss; if you please, miss!—and they were so ignorant too!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Dear, yes!—They did not know how to dance, nor to draw, nor to do fine work.—What stupid children!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Now you have made me think of them, I shall laugh if Miss Rosetta should be like them.—Harriot, don't make me laugh when she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Don't you make me laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Maria.
SP.P: But—Miss Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort, (to her.)
SP.P: Hush—let them alone—this will be a lesson for them—they think I don't hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Mama, did you speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Yes to Maria.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
When will this girl
come?—I dare say she is afraid—she thinks she shall look awkward.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: I fancy she is not much mistaken!
SP.STAGE: (A rap is heard at the parlour door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Pray come in.—Matilda open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh dear mama, (laughs.)—Harriot, have done laughing.
SP.STAGE: (Rosetta comes in, she curtsies mo∣destly. Her dress and manner should be plain, but not awk∣ward. Matilda and Harriot stare at her, and stifle a laugh.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Come in, my dear. I am very glad to see you, How do your father and mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta:
SP.P: Very well, thank you, ma'am; they desired their respects to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
I am very
much obliged to them.—Matilda, come and speak to Miss Rosetta, and take her bonnet.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: To wait upon her indeed.
SP.STAGE: (She advances affectedly and proudly towards Rosetta.)
SP.P: How do you do, ma'am? I am glad to see you.—Give me leave to take your cloak.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Thank you, ma'am; pray don't trouble yourself.
SP.STAGE: (Matilda takes away her cloak, &c. laughing aside at Harriot.—Rosetta sees them, blushes, and looks uneasy.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: It is a fine day, Miss Rosetta.—The country be∣gins to look very pleasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: What says your father to the present appear∣ance of the corn?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: He thinks it promises very fair, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort, (to Matilda.)
SP.P: Why don't you go and talk to Miss Rosetta.—I am ashamed of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda, (in a low voice.)
SP.P: Dear mama, what should I say to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Fye, you silly child!—Maria come with me, I am going to dress; and by the time I return, I hope young people you will be better acquainted. Matilda, do all you can to amuse Miss Rosetta. Harriot, be sure you behave properly.
SP.STAGE: (A long pause, during which all the children look confused.)

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot, (to Matilda.)
SP.P: Why don't you speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda, (aloud.)
SP.P: Be quiet, Har∣riot, you are the most provoking child!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Child!—to be sure!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: What, you think yourself a woman, I suppose, at nine years old!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Why not, as well as you at ten?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Such nonsense!—Miss Rosetta, will you like to look at my books?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: If you please, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot,
SP.P: Is not this a very pretty thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Will you play with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I don't know how.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot,
SP.P: There you must let it fall, and then jerk the string a little—you see it winds up; there, you must keep it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta,
SP.P: Is that right▪

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Yes, very right; you will soon do it. O, but you must not jerk it so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: What do you call it, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: A bandalore; some call them, Prince of Wales's toys.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, don't you know?—They are all the fashion. The Prince of Wales brought them in.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: They are pretty, but there is no great ingenuity in play∣ing with them, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh no, it is all a knack.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I like better a play, thing which requires more skill, or else is an exercise.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: So do I.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: But you said, ma'am, you would shew me your books.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: So I will—(To Har∣riot.)—She speaks prettily.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Yes, she does not seem stupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta, (looking at the books.)
SP.P: Oh, here is the Friend of Youth, and the Tales of the Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Yes, can you read them in French.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: No, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, they are charm∣ing in French.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I dare say they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Should you not like to learn French?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, but my father says it is not proper for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Do you learn to dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: No, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Dear, not to dance!—oh, that is best of all; I love dancing. Harriot, let us dance Mr. Duport's Cadrille. Shall you like to see us?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: If you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Now the Scotch steps Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh! I am out of breath—I love the Scotch reels, and they are very fashionable now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: It is very pretty in∣deed, and you dance vastly well.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh no, you flatter me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: No indeed—I hope you have not so bad an opinion of me.—Perhaps, indeed, I am no judge.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh yes, I dare say you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Yes, because she ad∣mires your dancing!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Harriot, you are very impertinent.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh, Miss Harriot on∣ly jests.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Not I, Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Very well, miss, I shall tell mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: As you like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: But, Miss Matilda, here is another book, which seems very pretty. Is it pretty?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Which do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Mrs. Barbauld's Hymns.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, that is a child's book, and so grave!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: A child's book!—why mama is very fond of it, and says it is beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I should like to read it.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, I'll lend it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I shall be extremely obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
Oh, you'll be very
welcome.—Pray do you learn to sing?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: No indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Your education seems to be very confined.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: You know I am only a farmer's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: There is something in that to be sure. I suppose, if you learn how to make butter, and sell eggs, your father is satisfied?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Not entirely with that.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I learn to sing.—Do you love singing?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, indeed very much.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Matilda wants to be asked to sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Harriot, you are ex∣cessively impertinent.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I am sure I shall be happy to hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, indeed, I am very hoarse.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Pray then don't trou∣ble yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Nay, to oblige you, I'll try.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Very pretty, indeed.—That is a charming song.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I declare, Miss Ro∣setta, you have a great deal of taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Have I?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: How simple she is!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: I like her very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: But if you neither dance nor sing, how do you contrive to fill up your time?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh, I have a great deal to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: I suppose she milks the cows!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: No, Miss Matilda, I don't.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: You thought I did not hear you!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: I beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh, I am not angry; if you are amused, that is enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: You are extremely good—I did not mean—

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: You did not mean to offend me. I know that one ought not to be angry at a jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: You are very oblig∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Now, Matilda, you are fairly caught; it serves you right.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Harriot, I did not ask you to interfere.
SP.STAGE: Mrs. Montfort and Maria come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: So, young peo∣ple!—Heyday, Matilda, what's the matter?—You look confused.—What have you been doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Nothing, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Oh, don't tell me that, I know better.—What was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Mama, she spoke im∣pertinently of Miss Rosetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
Harriot, that is a great fault, but it is a greater to be so eager to accuse your sister. My children, learn, that if you fail to conceal and excuse the errors of each other, the world will still more eagerly publish, and still more bitterly condemn them.—Where, alas! shall those who are faulty, look for pity and forgiveness, if not to those kindred bosoms who, knowing their failings, know also their virtues.—If we ourselves point the arrows of satire and re∣proach, at our sisters and our friends, who will hold before them the
shield of allowance and pardon!—This is not, however, intended to excuse you, Matilda. I am sorry, indeed, to hear you have behaved ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, indeed it was a mere jest, a trifle, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Very well, my dear, if you are satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: It is more than I deserve.—Mama, I was very much to blame.—I ask your pardon Rosetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Indeed, Miss Matilda, I am not offended. I am sorry to have caused you any uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: You are a very good girl. I hope both your com∣panions will profit by your exam∣ple.—Let us go to dinner.

DIV2.HEAD: The Little Country Visitor.
PART II.
DIV2.STAGE: Matilda, Harriot, and Rosetta, enter from the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: YOU will like our garden, I think, Miss Rosetta; it is very pleasant, and you cannot imagine how we enjoy it, after be∣ing so long in Philadelphia.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I imagine you were very much confined there.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
Yes, indeed.—You know we lived in Chesnut-Street; every morning, before breakfast; we walked with our governess,
and Maria, up and down the square for an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: The square—but is it like a garden?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, no, there are houses on every side, and where we walk is only a pavement; so it is merely for exercise, and tiresome enough I can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Oh, but you know sometimes we went to the State-House.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, the State-House—yes, that is very fine to be sure.—There we have a long gravel walk, with trees on each side, and full of people.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: What! no grass walks?—nor flowers?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Flowers!—Oh no, you might look for seven years without finding one.—And on the grass we must not walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh dear how sad!—I should hate that.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh yes, it is fright∣ful indeed.—Sometimes we went to Harrow gate-gardens, which are charming, but not often.—Well, now we are in the country, we shall walk a great deal.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: We have charming walks.—If Mrs. Montfort will give me leave, I will shew them to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, thank you, we shall like that vastly.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Perhaps too you know how to plant flowers, and manage them.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I have a large piece of garden, which I keep in order.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: What, all yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P:
No, the man digs it, and puts it in order; I sow the feeds, water them, tie up the flow∣ers
when they are blown, and do all that is not very fatiguing.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: How very agreeable!—What flowers have you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Honeysuckles, roses, carnations, stocks, and a great va∣riety of others, and also a large bed of thyme for my bees.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Your bees!—Have you bees also?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh, yes, three hives.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, charming!—You are not afraid of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Dear no!—I never dis∣turb them, and they do not hurt me.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Are they troublesome to keep?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Not at all. I have only to give them a little honey in the winter, to observe when they are going to swarm, and to provide a hive.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: To swarm—what is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: When the hive becomes too full, a great number of young bees go out of it, to find another place, where they make their comb and put the honey.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Where do they get the honey?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: From the flowers. They suck it out with a sort of trunk; in passing through their bags it becomes honey. They also roll themselves in t yellow dust of flowers, which makes the wax.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: That is very curious!—You know all that!—We do not know any thing of the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh, it is soon learned.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I should like to keep bees.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Perhaps, mama, will let us.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: But we do not know how to manage them.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: I will shew you, with all my heart, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, thank you, thank you; how good you are!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: And to plant flowers also?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, surely.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, delightful!—Ro∣setta, what flower is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: A larkspur—Here is another, of a different colour.—They are various in colour, and some are double.—They are annu∣als.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: What do you mean by annuals?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: They last but one year.—the seed must be saved, and sow∣ed again. Most of our common flowers are annuals.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
Oh, but you forget
roses, honeysuckles, lilacs, and jas∣mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Those are called flow∣ering shrubs.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: How much you know!—We know nothing of all this!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Oh, there is nothing more easy, when one lives in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: But you have been taught all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Not at all; I need on∣ly observe.—I do not need telling.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: And we know nothing but what we are taught.—And yet we fancy ourselves very wise!—No wonder your time is employed!—What else do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P:
I work a great deal.—I read whenever I can: I make cakes, and pastry: I help to gather the fruit in season, and to cull flowers and herbs for distilling: I
manage the poultry-yard, and over∣look the dairy.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, how clever you are!—I wish I could do so.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: There is nothing clev∣er in that; I only do my duty.—You are differently situated, you have no need of these things.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: For all that, they are more useful.—But if we did what mama wishes us, that would be enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: To be sure it is.—You do, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: No, truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: No.—Mama wishes us to read more; not to be conceited; to spend less time idly; to talk less ourselves, and attend more to other people.—Not to be imperti∣nent; and above all not to quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: No doubt, you obey such reasonable, and kind com∣mands.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Yes—when we re∣member!—But to-day—I see now how foolishly I have behaved!—How ignorant, I fancied you were, because you could not dance and sing!—How I chattered to you without attending to what you said!—Then I was very impertinent to you, and quarrelled with Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: But, dear Miss Matil∣da, how I love you for owning your faults!—You will soon mend them.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Ah!—I fear not!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Yes, since you know them so well!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: You allow, then, I have faults; I love you for that: every body else, except Mama, my Governess, and Maria flatter me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: To flatter!—Oh, how vile!

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Do they not flatter you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P:
No, surely; I should
espise any one who did.—What! ake us more faulty, by pretend∣ing to think us perfect?—Is it not ?—Such people must either wish us to be blameable out of ill-nature, that they may ridicule us, or mean to make some advantage of our faults.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I believe you are right; I shall be more cautious in future.—Rosetta promise to tell me when I am wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Ah! have you not a mother, much more capable than I am of telling you?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Yes; but I behave better when mama sees me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: And why?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Because I know she will love me better

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: What then does she wish you to seem good, or really to be so?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, really to be so without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Then you do not an∣swer her wishes, if you are le good when she does not see you, than when she does.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Very true indeed!—Oh, you shall see I will be very good henceforward.—We shall have you with us often, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Certainly; I shall be happy, if Mrs. Montfort pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, I am sure she will like it.—Here comes mama.—I shall ask her.—Harriot, you will like it too; shall you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: Oh yes, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda,
SP.P: Mama mama!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Well!—What say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
Mama, will you not
e Miss Rosetta to come and see ?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Yes, certainly, often as she can make it conve∣nient to come to you.—At all yours, my dear Rosetta; if the chil∣dren are taking their lessons, they all not disturb themselves; you ill not perhaps be sorry to be of e party.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Thank you, ma'am, ou are very kind indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: I see, Matilda, this request, that at last you un∣derstand the merit of your compan∣ion.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Oh, yes, indeed, mama!—She knows so much; she understands flowers, and how to keep bees, and to make cakes, and many other things.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
Yes—and that not all.—She helps her mother
to instruct her sisters, in working reading, and writing.—Besides the assistance she gives in houshold af∣fairs, she works excellently we at her needle.—She is fond of read∣ing, and has greatly improved by it.—I beg your pardon, Rosetta for commending you to your face but I wish to give my children lesson, who fancied this morning, because you had not the same ad∣vantages with themselves; you must be ignorant and awk ward. They now see you are neither; and the begin to know how much mo valuable and useful are your em∣ployments than theirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Indeed, ma'am, the young ladies were not mistaken; am very ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
You are very modest; which will, I hope, be another lesson to them.—Beside
Matilda, Miss Rosetta is not de∣ficient in those lighter accomplish∣ments which you admire so much.—She has taught herself to design landscapes, and to paint flowers, charmingly well, and she also sings very agreeably.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: What! Rosetta, can you sing?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: But—very little indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: You did not say so this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: You only asked me, if I had learn'd; and, I said, I had not; which is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Mama, I am quite convinced of what you have so of∣ten told me, that by chatting so much, attending so much to my∣self, and so little to other people, I lose a great deal of pleasure and instruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
Yes.—If you
had not chosen to display what you fancied your superiority, in danc∣ing and singing, to Miss Rosetta, you would earlier have learnt her merit, and the power she has of teaching you many useful and a∣greeable things.—You would have saved yourself the pain of being impertinent to her, and me the mortification of seeing you rude, saucy, and conceited.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Mama—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Indeed, you were all these!—But, hence for∣ward, Matilda, I hope you will reflect, that the light frivolous ac∣complishments you have boasted of so much, are in reality of no essen∣tial import, since they neither make us more wise, more humble, or more pleasing in our behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P:
But mama, do you not
then wish us to learn singing and dancing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Certainly.—It is a duty incumbent on you to learn them, because I wish it, and be∣cause they are ornamental parts of education, suited to the place you are to ill in life.—But I would not have you fancy they make you at all superior to those whose situ∣ation excludes them from such in∣formation.—You will do very wrong not to learn them, but you have no merit in possessing them, as every other person would do the same, if they had the same oppor∣tunity.—And I would have you always consider, that one precept which teaches you to improve your behaviour, or regulate your temper, is of more value than the finest singing, or most graceful dancing.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I am sure you are right, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P: Even superior acquirements ought not to render you proud or conceited.—If you read more, or write better, than o∣ther children of your age; if you know better how to behave, or have better qualities, you ought to reflect that all have not equal advantages with yourself.—Every child has not a father, who can or will be at the expence of having her well in∣structed.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Ah, mama, nor has every child a mother who takes such pains in teaching her!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
That is true,—Learn then to make allowances for differences of natural capacity, which we have no merit in posses∣sing, as we did not give it to our∣selves; and for difference of edu∣cation,
which depends on those a∣bout us,—When these allowances are made, we shall seldom, if ever, find any thing to ridicule or des∣pise; pity, and a wish to amend, will be our only sentiments.—And when we consider how many oppor∣tunities we have ourselves lost, how much more we might have learned, than we have learned, we may easily allow for those who have even lost more time than ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Ah, mama, I feel how much you are in the right; and I promise you henceforth to be more attentive, and less presuming.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriot.
SP.P: And I also, indeed, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosetta.
SP.P: Ah, ma'ma, let me too thank you for these valuable in∣structions; which, I hope, will be also profitable to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Montfort.
SP.P:
You are a very
good girl, my dear Rosetta.—I hope you will come hither often, and that the connection will be mu∣tually useful.—Let us go in; it is tea-time.

FIGURE.HEAD: The Distrest Family. Vilmats distress relieved by Mr. and Miss Barclay

Q.L: Such fate to suffering worth is given,
Who long with wants and woes has striven;
By cruel fraud and cunning driven
To misery's brink.
'Till wrench'd of every stay, save Heav'n,
He ruin'd sunk.

DIV2.HEAD: THE DISTREST FAMILY.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE before a Cottage, with a small railed Garden, a distant view of a Village, the Church, &c.—
Wilmot comes out of the Cottage.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
THE Sun is arisen; the mists are partly dispelled.—How pure is the air!—For a moment let me try to forget my cares, and enjoy these refresh∣ing odours.—(He pauses.)—Oh, how vain the attempt!—These scenes, the moment of day-break, once so delicious to my heart, to
