which it used to expand with so much rapture, have lost their power!—Oh, my God, it was here I used to offer to thee my morning sacri∣fice of praise and prayer. It was here, softened into universal bene∣volence, I used to pray for all men.—I no longer feel those delightful emotions.—A weight of grief hangs upon my heart. The ardour of my devotion is departed. My wishes are contracted to a point.—I have lost my hopes on earth; and, I fear, I am also losing my trust in God.—Oh, my heavenly father, deign to hear me!—Suffer me not to despair of thy mercies, or to murmur at thy will!—Teach me to support my anguish, if not with the fortitude of a man, with the resignation of a christian!(He leans against a tree, with his face on his arms, in thought.)
Rachel enters from the cottage; as she shuts the door, she looks back▪ and says.—Be quiet, George—don't make a noise, I shall be back in a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: Father, my dear father, why are you so sad?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: My child!

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Indeed, father, my mo∣ther is better.—She sleeps.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P:
She will soon sleep in death!—Must I see her die!—Without friends, without the means of procuring her proper as∣sistence, I see her languishing un∣der a disease which might be cured, could I but obtain proper nourish∣ment for her.—Why do I hesitate!—Driven from men, as if I did not belong to their species, the bands between me and society are broken;
wherefore then should I not fall, like a beast of prey, on those bar∣barous wretches who leave us to perish.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: Father you did not bid me pray to-day, but I have prayed.—Why do you not teach me to be good, as you used to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Oh, my child!—My God! thou hast made this innocent my preser∣ver.—Are the bands between me and society broken!—Oh no! my children are ties which I dare not break.—Thou hast trusted them to me!—Dare I corrupt thy work, and lead those to wickedness and misery whom thou hast created to be good and happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: What do you mean, father?—Why do you cry—why do you speak so hastily—are you angry with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: No, my child, no I—Happy innocent!—thou know∣est not the force of the passions!—thou readest not the anguish of a heart, fluctuating between good and evil.—Go my child to thy mo∣ther; she may want thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: I will, father.—(As she goes out, she meets Mr. John∣son.—She curtsies, but he takes no notice.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: How cross he looks!—I hope he won't scold my father!—What can make people so cross, I wonder!

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Good-day to you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: Ser∣vant, George.—What art doing here; why dost not get to work man?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
Sir, I am going to work; but my wife has been ill all night.—I fear for her life.—I
know not how to leave her, lest I should see her no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: Well, well, man, if thee dost not work, thy wife can∣not eat, nor thy children neither: that's all I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Alas, Sir, I would I were able to work incessantly, for their sakes; would that I could live without rest, that I might earn more for their support.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: Well, then, why dost stand idle?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, it is not idle∣ness, my strength, and my spirits fail me, but never my wish to la∣bour.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: How thou talk'st of thy strength, and thy strength; hast not as much strength as ano∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: At least, Sir, what have I employ willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P:
Don't know that.—
Thou dost not as much work in a day and a half, as some of my men do in a day.—George, George, I am afraid thee art lazy and then thy wife, she is sick.—She says so however; she can't do this, and she can't do that; her betters can do it.—God knows how you contrive to live!

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P: Yes, Sir!—God does know!—He sees our hearts; he knows whether or not I wish to work; whether or not my poor Agnes is really sick.—Ah, Heaven, I can bear any thing for myself, but I have not yet learnt to bear reproach on her!

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: Well, well, George, thou seem'st not to be cut out for a working man, thou look'st and talk'st like a gentleman, so may be thou know'st how to live like one, I'am sure I've no objection.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P: What cruel in∣sults!—Down proud and rebellious spirit.—I will be humble! (To Johnson.)—Ah, Sir, gentlemen do not live as I live; gentlemen do not see those they love dying be∣fore their eyes, without the pow∣er of giving them assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: I'll tell thee what, George; if thou can'st afford to stand chattering here all day, I cannot.—So fare thee well; since thou hast not a mind to work, I must find somebody who has.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Good heavens, Sir!—I am going to work instantly; do not, I conjure you, do not think of employing another.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: Well, well, I shall see about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: But, Sir, hear me, I pray you: promise me that you will not employ another.—Consi∣der my poor wife and children.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: 'Tis for thee to consi∣der them, and work the harder.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, you need not fear me; you shall have no reason to complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Johnson.
SP.P: We shall see that.—Go to work.—The men have been in the fields this half hour. Make haste, and we shall see.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: I shall, Sir. (John∣son goes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
Oh God!—Oh God!—hear my groans! Pity me, and teach this cruel man to pity me!—Make me forget I ever was, what I am not now!—Oh that I could acquire at once the strength and hu∣mility of the hardy peasant!—My blood rises, my heart swells; hardly could I restrain myself from answering this tyrant as he deser∣ved.—Let me see my Agnes once
more, and then hasten to obey this imperious master.
SP.STAGE: (He goes into the cottage, then comes cut again, crosses the stage, and goes out. Rachel and George follow him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Good-bye, father good-bye.—Come, George, let us go and get some sticks, to boil the po∣tatoes.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But mother will want you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: No, she says she is bet∣ter.—She will not eat any break∣fast, however.—She does not like bread.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I like it—but I like it best with an apple.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, but apples are scarce.—Our tree had but a few, and those must be saved for mother: she can eat a bit now and then.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P:
I am sure, then, I don't
want them.—I had rather she had them.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: I am sure I wish I could live without eating, that mama might have better things.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Mama! You must not say that.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, I had forgot; I must never say, mama, since Nan∣cy Johnson laughed at me, and her mother scolded me for saying so.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I hate Nancy Johnson; she's so proud and ill-temper'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, but you must not ate any body.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Well, I will hate Mrs. Johnson, however, because she's so cross to mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: You will hate her.—I cannot help laughing at that.
SP.STAGE: (While they are laughing, Mr. Bar∣clay and Eleonora come in.)

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Dear papa, what pret∣ty children.—What's your name my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: Rachel Wil∣mot, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: A very pretty name, and I dare say you are a very good girl.—Is that your brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: And what were you laughing at so heartily, my dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: At—a George, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: What did he say then?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Ma'am, he says he w hate Mrs. Johnson.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay,
SP.P: A very kind determination.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh dear, ma'am, bu pray don't tell her.—Perhaps you know her.—Pray don't be angry, e is but a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Be easy, I don't know her; and if I did, I should not tell her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, I'm glad of that.—Perhaps it might ruin my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: How so, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Sir my father works for Mr. Johnson; and, perhaps, they might be affronted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Very likely.—We will not tell them. Be good children—mind your book.—Let me see you at church, and here is six-pence for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: (joyfully.) Oh dear Sir, will you be so kind then as to let me work for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Work, my child!—What work can'st thou do?—Why, do'st think I will give the work?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Will you not, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: I have none for you, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Then, Sir, what am I to do with this money?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Keep it, my child.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Sir, my father says, I must not take money till I can work for it.—He forbids me to beg.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Charming little creature!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: How amiable!—But, my dear, you did not beg; my papa gave it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: But I don't think my father would like me to have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Her integrity i charming!—Look then, my child, I want those flowers which grow yonder.—I will give you six-pence to gather them for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, yes, Sir, yes.

STAGE.HI:
(She runs and gathers the flowers.
Mr. Barclay gives her the six-pence, and the flowers to Eleo∣nora.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Keep them, my Eleonora, and if ever you should be tempted to forget my precepts, let them remind you how well this little cottager kept those of her fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: I can never forget it.—Adieu, Rachel. I shall see you again some time or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Good-bye, ma'am.—Thank you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P:
O, George, see!—I have got six-pence!—I shall go di∣rectly to the village, and buy mo∣ther some biscuits, such as she likes, and some coffee: I can have both for six-pence.—Go in—don't tell her where I am gone.—If she wants
any thing, Dame Green will come if you call her.—Don't make a racket.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No, no.—Good-bye.
SP.STAGE: (Rachel goes out. George goes into the cottage.)

DIV2.HEAD: The Distrest Family.
PART II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, the Inside of the Cottage.
Agnes, Rachel, George.—A small ta∣ble stands by Agnes, with coffee, and buiscuits.—A little inner room is seen, with a bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: BUT, mother, you don't eat the buiscuits.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Yes, my dear, I have eaten one; take one yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: No, thank ye, mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: I am not hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: My child, there are more than I can eat; you may take one safely.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: But, mother, they will not be spoiled by to-morrow, and they are better for you than bread.—I like bread very much.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: My dear Rachel! (em∣braces her with tears.)—My God, I thank the for the blessing of such affectionate children: they comfort me in all my distresses! Rachel see if your father is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: No, mother, it is twelve o'clock too; how very hot it is!

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Alas, how my poor Wil∣mot will be fatigued.—He exhausts his strength in working for us.—I dare not wish to die, for I know how much my death would afflict him!—And my poor children, they yet need a mother's care!

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Mother, my dear mo∣ther, why do you cry; my father will soon be here.

SP.SPEAKER: George,
SP.P: Don't cry, mother, my father is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Do not tell him I have been crying.—I am better now; how near is he?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Mother, he is just get∣ting over the stile; he looks up to the sky; he wipes his face.—Ah, how hot he is; I will run out to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Ah, how he must be fatigued!—In this burning Sun—he that was so delicately bred!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Here he is, mother—here he is!

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: My dear Wilmot!—How tired you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel,
SP.P: Sit down here father; let me take your hat.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: The Sun is so hot!—My dear Agnes, how are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Better, thank you!—Rachel has procured me some cof∣fee; it has done me good.—Take a cup of it, it will refresh you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: What is the matter?—You look pale. Oh, Wilmot, speak to me, for God's sake.—You are ill?—Ah, he is dying. He has killed himself for me!

STAGE.HI: (Wilmot fainting, leans back. Agnes runs for water, and sprinkles him. Rachel and George scream. Rachel rus to the door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Help, help!—Oh, my father is dying. Mother, mother, don't you die too.

SP.SPEAKER: George,
SP.P: Oh, mother mo∣ther!
SP.STAGE: (A knocking at the door.—Af∣ter a while, it is repeated.)

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Wilmot, Wilmot speak to me, speak to me.

STAGE.HI: (The knocking is heard again. Rachel opens the door. Mr. Barclay and Eleonora come in. Agnes still hangs over Wilmot, in the greatest agony.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: What is the mat∣ter, good people—What occasion∣ed the screams I heard?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, my father is dead, and my mother is dying.—George, George, let us die too!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: My dear, don't be frighten'd—he is not dead, he will soon recover. (To Agnes.) Pray don't be so terrified.
SP.STAGE: (Agnes looks only at Wilmot. El∣eonora takes out her salts; ap∣plies them to Wilmot. Mr. Barclay supports him)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: My good wo∣man, recover yourself; he is only faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P:
Oh no, he is dead.—
I have killed him. Wilmot, I shall not out-live you.
SP.STAGE: (Wilmot begins to recover; half raises his head, and looks at Ag∣nes.—In a moment he speaks.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: My wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: I am here—I am at your side.—I will not leave you even in death.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: My dearest Agnes, I am better; do not terrify your∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Indeed there is no need—he will be well presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Ah, Madam, I beg your pardon.—I fear I have been troublesome to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: By no means; your wife and children have been sadly alarmed.—Pray prevail on your wife to take some care of herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Agnes, I entreat you to sit down.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora,
SP.P: Take a little water, will you?—Rachel, shew me where it is, I will fetch some.
SP.STAGE: (She fetches water, and obliges Agnes to drink of it, who is re∣lieved by a violent fit of cry∣ing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Thank you ma'am; you are extremely good.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Have you been ill long, my friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: No, Sir, I was very well this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Ah, my dear Wilmot you have over-worked yourself.—This burning Sun—Your cares, your anxiety, have overcome you!—Why would you do so?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: My dear Agnes, if you knew the terrors I have suffer∣ed!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: The terrors!

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, of being de∣prived of my work. My master threatened me this morning with dismission; he accuses me of lazi∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Oh, what you!—You who have worked so eagerly, so constantly?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
Alas, yes!—Unable before to procure for you, my dear Agnes, the support your disease re∣quired, could I bear the idea of losing the common necessaries for you, and for my children?—Nor was this all, the cruel man added the most bitter and unprovoked re∣flections on me, and those I love best.—I left you, Agnes, this morn∣ing half heart broken, and scarcely able to resolve on longer enduring a miserable existence, except for those dear sakes, whose remember∣ance
urged me on beyond my strength!

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Ah, Wilmot, to us then you owe your illness, even perhaps your death; to us who would have died to save you!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Father, let me help you to work to-morrow; perhaps Mr Johnson won't scold then.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Alas, my child!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Pray tell me, who is this oppressive man, this Johnson, of whom you speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Sir, he is the farmer who employs me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Where does he live?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: In a farm called Oat∣ley, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P:
I thought so!—It is my farm, and he is now urging me for a new lease, on terms very favourable to himself.—I am glad
to learn how I ought to deal with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: I should be sorry, Sir, to prejudice you against him; he is honest, and a good farmer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: You do your∣self honour, by thus repaying his unkindness; but he must not expect me to favour a man capable of such conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, ma'am, for not asking you to sit down.—We are exceedingly in∣debted to you for the trouble you have taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Not in the least.—I would not be impertinent; but—can we be of service to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P: Vain prejudice, which has so long taught me to conceal my distresses, begone!—Unable longer to labour, I must apply to the compassion of others, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Speak freely, my good friend.—Can I assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, the dear wo∣man you see has been ill a long time; she is better, but her weak state requires nourishment, which I cannot procure for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: My dear Wilmot, think more of yourself, and less of me.—It is he, Sir, who requires your assistance.—I have already taken refreshment, which your kindness this morning enabled my child to procure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: What! my little flower-gatherer!—Amiable child!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: My good friend, your husband seems much recovered; you are yourself indisposed, be prevailed on to lie down; in the mean time my father will learn how he can be of use to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Do, my dear Agnes; I am quite well.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Since you request it, I will obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Let me help you?

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Oh no!—dear young lady, I cannot bear you should wait on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Why not?—It is a pleasure to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: But it is giving you so much trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Not at all.—I dare say, if I were sick, and you were well, you would wait on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: Most surely.—It would be fit I should be your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: To be sure, it is al∣ways fit those who are in health should wait on those who are sick.

SP.SPEAKER: Agnes.
SP.P: What sweetness!
SP.STAGE: (She goes out, leaning on Eleono∣ra, followed by Rachel; in a minute Eleonora returns.)

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.STAGE: (in a low voice, to her fa∣ther.)
SP.P: Sir, these poor people have great need of refreshment, let me fetch it from home, I will return present∣ly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Do so, but do not run, it is too hot.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: I will not.
SP.STAGE: (Mr. Barclay, Wilmot, George at a distance.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: My child will soon return; she is gone for refresh∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, how can I thank you for your goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: My good friend, why would you not apply to me before?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
Sir, while I was able by the work of my hands, to pro∣cure for my wife and children the means of life, I had no right to
encroach upon the goodness of others, or on that relief which poorer wtetches had a better right to.—But when my strength failed me; when I saw myself on the point of being deprived of work, and my children of bread, it became time to ask, and God has been pleas∣ed that I should not ask in vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: I admire your sentiments, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Father, my mother is inclined to sleep, but every time her eyes close she starts and fancies she ees you fainting again.—If you go to her, perhaps, she will be easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P:
Go, my friend, no apologies; I will chat awhile
with Rachel; I shall tell you a charming story of her.
SP.STAGE: (Wilmot goes in. Rachel stands by Mr. Barclay.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Will my mother get well soon, Sir, do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: I hope so my dear: has she been ill long?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh yes, Sir, a great while: all the winter she had a cough, but it is gone; but she is so weak, and then she cannot eat bread and potatoes, as we do.—I bought her some coffee to-day, with the money I had from you, Sir.—She took some.—I was so pleased!—But my father frighted us sadly!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Did you ever see him so before?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: No, Sir; he is often tired very much indeed, but not so bad.—To be sure, he has not been used to such hard work.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: What work then has he been used to, my child?

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Why, Sir, it is a great while ago, before George can re∣member, we lived in a nice house, and had servants, and I had white frocks, and fine people used to come and see us!—But now the fine people don't come, Sir; why don't they?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Happy innocent▪—Thou knowest not how eagerly the great fly from the unfortunate!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: My dear!—What, have you carried that bas∣ket thro' the heat?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P:
No, Sir, I thought you would not be pleased, so I made John bring it to the gate, but I would not let him come in
for these people seem to have so much feeling, I could not bear to bring an unnecessa witness of their distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay,
SP.P: (embracing her.) My dear girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Rachel, see if your mother is asleep.
SP.STAGE: (Rachel goes into the inner room. Wilmot comes out.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: My poor Agnes can get no rst.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: I will go to her.—I have brought some drops, which will compose her spirits.

STAGE.HI: (Sh kes cut of the basket a bot∣tle of wine, two glasses, slices of cold ham, and bread and cakes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Papa, will you eat something?—Perhaps Mr. Wilmot will take a glass of wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P:
(aside.) Charming deli∣cacy!
—How I feel that kindness!
SP.STAGE: (Eleonora goes into the inner room. Mr. Barclay and Wilmot sit at the table. Rachel and George creep towards them. Mr. Barclay gives them cakes. They all eat.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot,
SP.P: Angelic charity!—Not content∣ed with furnishing the means of health, she administers them her∣self, waiting with humility and sweetness on the poor and wretch∣ed

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: There is nothing extraordinary in that; one know what it is to be ill, and leave those who are so to the unfeeling attendance of servants, or merce∣nary nurses?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: No; you cannot.—Warm and feeling, your hearts make the distresses of others your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: That is no mat∣ter of wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Oh! not to you.—Goodness is to you too common to be wonderful.—But to me, to me who have been rejected by the world, cast off by my relations, such kindness is scarcely credible!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Your lot seems to have been an hard one, but let it not make you think ill of all mankind.—There seems to be something uncommon in your story and if the recital be not painful—

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: The recital, Sir, I thank God, will not be painful, for I have no guilt of my own to relate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: I dare engage it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
Perhaps, of some im∣prudence, you will not so easily ac∣quit me.—I was born to a good estate; just after I came of age,
my father died; soon after, I married that dear woman you have seen.—She was of good family, but had no fortune; mine was sufficient for us both, but fond as I was of my Agnes, desiring to pro∣cure for her every indulgence, I lived to the extent of my income, and far beyond her wishes: for five years we lived happily, when a distant relation of the person from whom my father had bought the estate, pretending a fault in the title, laid claim to it; the cause was tried, and by an artifice my chief witness kept out of court. I lost my cause, and was left desti∣tute; my relations excusing them∣selves on account of my marrying, as they called it, imprudently, and my living expensively, refused me any assistance, and with the rest of my friends, turned their back upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: What cruel con∣duct!

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: One friend alone was left, who received us into his house, and would have procured a re-hear∣ing of our cause, but he died, and we were sent forth to wander through the world. I hired this cottage, where, by the labour of my hands, I have supported my wife, that dear consoling angel, who has never once reproached me for the misery I have brought upon her, and our children; till her sickness drove me almost to dis∣traction and despair, from which Heaven sent you this day to relieve me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Make yourself easy, I hope all will be well; our first care must be to restore your wife.—Is the person yet alive who was to have witnessed in your cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: He is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Very well, My dear Wilmot hear me, I am tol∣erably rich, I have only one child, I will support you in this cause if, on enquiry, I find you are like∣ly to succeed, and I will only a in return your promise to repay me when you regain your estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Sir—such amazing kindness to a stranger!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: No, Wilmot, not to a stranger. I knew your father well; he was my senior at college. I have often heard of this cause as a most iniquitous transac∣tion, and I have no doubt of your success, so that all the favour I do you is to advance you a little mo∣ney; no mighty obligation!

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Oh yes!—My obli∣gations to you are mighty, are not to be repaid!—Best of men!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Psha! there are thousands better.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Such amazing generosi∣ty!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: There is really no generosity in the matter.—I am sure of my security.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: What, Sir!—The word of a person you do not know▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: No, Wilmot, not of a person I do not know.—I have seen enough of you to convince me you are honest and grateful; what better security should I desire?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: I am overpowered!—My children, bless your benefac∣tor!

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, will you make my father and mother well and happy?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And will you give my mother something better to eat than potatoes?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Oh yes, my children, he will save us all.—Thank him then; learn to love and serve him; keep about you—never forget the form of this cottage; and if, as I hope, we live to inhabit a better place, remember always who res∣cued us from poverty!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: No more, no more; if you will think yourself obliged to me, in return do me the favour not to thank me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Mr. Wilmot, your wife is asleep; she will be well, I dae say—and you, how are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Oh, well, quite well!—The blessing of Heaven accompa∣nies you; all must be well where you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P:
Wilmot think of what I have said to yo. In the evening I will send my car∣riage
to bring you all to my house, where you shall remain, either till your cause is gained, or, if that cannot be, till I can place you in some way of life better suited to your birth. (To Eleonora.) My dear, Mr. Wilmot is entitled to a very large fortune, which I hope to procure for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: I am very glad of i, but fortune cannot add to my res∣pect for people so worthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Angelic creature!—How can I ever want—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: You forget my injunctions!—I shall send for you—be ready.—In the mean time; take care of yourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: What, father, shall we ride in a coach?

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P:
Yes, my dear, often, every day, if you continue good: and, what is better, you shall have
a great many charming little books.

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Oh, how glad I shall be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Barclay.
SP.P: Wilmot, Fare∣wel!

SP.SPEAKER: Eleonora.
SP.P: Farewel, Mr. Wil∣mot.—Good-bye, Rachel; we shall except you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P: Every blessing attend you!

SP.SPEAKER: Rachel.
SP.P: Thank you, thank you.
SP.STAGE: (She kisses Eleonora's hand, who embraces her.—Wilmot attends Mr. Barclay to the door, and returns.)

SP.SPEAKER: Wilmot.
SP.P:
Oh my God!—How can I ever thank thee, for such a∣mazing goodness!—Heart broken, wearied, on the point of renouncing my dependance on thee; of eting thy laws at defiance; that mo∣ment hast thou chosen to relieve and bless me!—Aweful and strik∣ing
lesson!—Shall I ever again despair, when I know that the next hour to that of our greatest misery may bring with it comfort and happiness!—I hear my Agnes coming; let me meet and explain to her these happy events!

DIV2.P: The limits of the Drama not allowing of the events being finished, it may per∣haps be satisfactory to the reader to hear, that Mrs. Wilmot recovered; and that Wilmot, gaining his cause, by Mr. Bar∣clay's means, was restored to affluence, and the two families formed a friend∣ship, which lasted during their lives.

Lady Aubrey,

DIV1.HEAD: THE VILLAGE WEDDING.
DIV1.STAGE: SCENE, a Lawn before a Cottage.

(Under the shade of some trees a ta∣ble is spread, with fruits, milk, and cyder. Robert, and some old peasants, sit at this table. Phi∣lip, Lucetta, and some young pea∣sants, are dancing on the lawn. Lucetta is dressed in white, with flowers, as a bride, Philip as a bridegroom.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: AYE, marry neigh∣bour, it does my heart good to see them,—Look ye there, I'll warrant ye as light as the best!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Peasant.
SP.P: Truly, neighbour Robert, Lucetta is a pretty girl; yes, yes, you may well be proud of her. She is not only handsome, but good.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah, neighbour!—She is the joy of my old heart!—Had her mother lived to see this day!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Peasant.
SP.P: Come cheerly, neighbour, don't let's disturb our∣selves with sad thoughts, we met to be merry. (Lucetta seeing her father look sad, out of the dance.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lucetta.
SP.P: Ah, father!—What's the matter?—You are not ill?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: No, no, my child, I am very well, and very happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucetta.
SP.P: Well, then!—why look sad!—on my wedding-day too!—Truly, I will not excuse it!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert,
SP.P: (taking her in his arms.) My child, I do not weep for sor∣row, but for joy, thou art so good, and so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucetta.
SP.P: Ah, my dear father, I owe both to you!—but not a single tear must you shed to-day.—Ah, ha, here comes Philip; he thinks something is the matter.
SP.STAGE: (She runs to Philip, gives him her hand, he leads her back to the dance.)

SP.SPEAKER: Old Peasant.
SP.P: Aye, aye, they are happy enough!—Well, they be a sweet couple.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.P:
As to Lucetta, I must say, I don't know her equal, nor ever did, except my poor daughter, that's gone.—Marry neighbour Robert, I have reason to love your girl; how kind she was to me, when my poor daugh∣ter lay sick.—Don't grieve so,
neighbour Martha, she would say, pray don't; I'll do all I can to fill your daughter's place.—Ah, and so she has; she tended me when I was sick; she works for me, now my eye-fight fails! Ah, marry, I love her as if she was my own!

SP.SPEAKER: Second Old Woman.
SP.P: Then she is so kind to the children; my little grand-daughters run when they see her coming—here's Lucetta, they say, here's Lucetta; truly, 'tis a holiday to see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah, it does my heart good, to hear her praises!—What a blessed thing it is to have every body's good word!

SP.SPEAKER: Old Peasant.
SP.P: Aye, Robert, that's the honest man's reward, to be well thought of himself, and leave a good name to his children!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P:
True, neighbour, true; but look, here's gentlefolk Mar∣ry,
'tis our young 'Squire, and his bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Old Woman.
SP.P: Yes, and that is my Lady's father, and her sister.—Mercy! how handsome they be!

DIV1.STAGE: Enter 'Squire and Lady Aubrey, Colonel and Miss Nesbit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: What a charm∣ing scene!—How happy these good people seem!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: This appears to be a wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Nesbit.
SP.P: Ah, that is the bride!—What a pretty creature, and how neat.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: That young man is the bridegroom, I fancy; how happy he looks!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Ah!—I see the bride's father!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: Where, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: The old pea∣sant, seated under the shade of those trees, and surrounded by his neigh∣bours.—I know him by the joy, the happiness of his looks!—yes, I am well acquainted with the sweet transports of beholding; daughter happily married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey,
SP.P: (kissing his hand.) Ah, my dear father, your, heart has led you to him.
SP.STAGE: (They advance; the old people rise up.)

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: Keep your seats, my good friends.—We are wil∣ling to share with you, but not to interrupt this happy scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Won't your Honour and my good Lady, please to sit down?

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: No, thank you, my old friend, we will stand near∣er the dancers; I love to see them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: We shall go a∣way, if we interrupt you good peo∣ple; pray take your seats again.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Thank your good La∣dyship.
SP.STAGE: ('Squire Aubrey, Lady Aubrey, and Miss Nesbit, walk towards the dancers.)

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: My honest friends, with your leave, I shall sit with you.—We will leave the young folks to themselves; we old ones can but look on now, though some years ago we could have dan∣ced with the best of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Your Honour is all goodness.
SP.STAGE: (He gives a chair. Col. Nes∣bit sits down, the Peasants seem to hesitate.)

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Come, come, sit down all of you; I insist upon it.
SP.STAGE: (They sit, Robert and the Colo∣nel a little apart from the rest.)

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: So, my good friend, this is a wedding, is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, your Honour; and I pray God it may prove a happy one.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.—That is the bride, I suppose; a pretty girl, truly.—I must drink to her health.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Sir, you do her honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: I need not to be told she is your daughter. I read in your face how much you are concerned in this affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, 'tis an affair of consequence, indeed!—The mar∣rying an only and dear child, is no light matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Most surely not; and, I dare say, you have taken care to marry her well.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P:
Yes, your Honour, well; I hope well. Philip is a
worthy, good young man.—He has been brought up in this village; I have known him ever since he was half the height of my stick, as I may say.—A good tempered lad.—"Neighbour, shall I do this for you; shall I do that.—Neigh∣bour, I am going to market; can I do any thing for you?" All that makes one love a lad.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: No doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: At last, Sir, I began to find out he liked my daughter.—That made me think a little.—Lucetta, they say, is pretty.—I know she is good: and farmer Thomas, who is main rich, had made her an offer, but the girl did not like him.—Marry, I can't say he is one of the best.—But I tire your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Not at all, my friend, not at all, I take pleasu in hearing you.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Your Honour is very kind.—To be sure, Philip is poor; and I cannot give my girl much: 'tis hard, your Honour, to fear one shall live to see one's children want!—But then, I bethought me that Philip is an industrious lad; and Lucetta knows how to manage very prettily.—"Father, (said Philip) if you give me Lucetta, don't fear while I have strength but we shall do very well.—I'll work for her while I can, and when I can work no longer, I hope God will take care of us." What could I say, your Honour? I could not refuse him, and so this morning they were married.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: You have done very right, my friend, and this must be a happy day to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P:
Ah, Sir, it is a happy day!—But yet not without its
cares.—I cannot think of the fu∣ture without some fear!—But I rely on Providence, and hope it will support a virtuous young cou∣ple, who will not spend their days in idleness.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P:
Good old man!—you need fear nothing.—Hear me, my friend!—I am a father my∣self; I have lately experienced what it is to marry away a daugh∣ter, dearer, far dearer than my life.—I know the cares, the anxieties of a father for the happiness of his child; but I cannot endure the idea of your suffering a care which I can remove so easily.—My good friend, I cannot ensure your child's future happiness; but, at least, I can contribute to it, and to your case, by removing your fears of future poverty for her. Happily, as I have married my daughter
with wealth beyond her wants or wishes, I cannot permit a man, a father like myself, to struggle with a fear so painful, as that of his daugh∣ter's future subsistence. (He takes out his pocket-book.) My good friend take these notes; this is worth an hundred pounds, this is worth fifty; the sum they will pro∣duce will sufficiently support you in your old age, and your children when death obliges you to quit them.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: But, your Honour—what—I do not understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: My good old man, these notes are yours.—Do me the favour to accept them.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Oh Heavens!—What goodness!—Is this possible!—Surely I dream!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P:
Ah, virtuous old man, let us not think a com∣mon
act of kindness so extraordina∣ry as to disbelieve its reality!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah, Sir!—a common act!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Let us say no more of it!—The notes are yours; and believe me. I feel more plea∣e in giving than you do in re∣ceiving them.—You will, perhaps, chuse to purchase a little farm; which may descend to your chil∣dren's children

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah, yes, Sir, and they shall learn to bless your name, to honour your goodness!—In spring, when they see the opening blossoms; in autumn, when they gather in harvest; they shall, next to their God, love and bless your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: My good old friend!—let me not hear any more of this.—I wish not to draw ob∣servation.

STAGE.HI: ('Squire and Lady Aubrey, Miss Nesbit, and Lucetta, come to∣wards them.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: What is the mat∣ter, my dear Sir?—you seem af∣fected.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucetta.
SP.P: Father, what is the matter—I saw you change colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, my child!—Come hither, Lucetta—all my cares for thee are at an end!—His Hon∣our!—Oh, best of men?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Nesbit.
SP.P: What does all this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: Tell us, my dear Sir—explain the cause of this good man's emotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Nothing, my children: nothing my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, pardon me; if I disobey you. Look here, my good Sir▪ see —His Honour has most liberally blessed me! (He shows the notes.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: Ah, my dear fa∣ther, what goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Dear Julia!—Blest as I am in my children, hap∣py as I feel in your marriage, could I bear to see a father full of care, which I could so easily re∣lieve?
SP.STAGE: (Lady Aubrey throws herself into his arms, while Miss Nesbit kisses his hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: My father, how my heart thanks you!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Silly girls!—What is there in all this to excite surprize?

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: No, my dear Sir, acts of goodness are with you too common to excite surprize; but I am angry with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P:
Yes, my dear Julia your father has invaded ou
rights.—We ought to assist and encourage such of our tenants as are deserving.—My good Robert well merits our attention, and your fa∣ther shall not rob us of the pleasure of assisting him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: I am quite of your opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: So, so, I am to be chid amongst you, it seems.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: Not if you will permit us to join your benevolent attentions.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Oh, with all my heart.
SP.STAGE: (During this conversation, Robert, Philip, and Lucetta, with great marks of pleasure and surprize, have been looking at the notes, and talking apart.)

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: Come hither, my friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Yes, please your Hon∣our▪

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: My good Robert I remember you many years, and from that remembrance, as well as the general report, I know you to be a worthy industrious man.—Had I been earlier at the Park, I should have known of this wedding before hand, and I should have thought it my duty to give you something towards your daughter's portion.—It is not yet too late.—Therefore, I promise you half a dozen sheep, two cows, two pigs, a stock of poultry, provided you make Lucetta the manager of your farm-yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Oh Heavens!—I am over powered.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P:
As to you, Philip, when a man is married, he ought to have a house for his wife; you shall therefore have the tenement next to Robert's with the field be∣hind it; for the first year it shall
be -free, after which we will agree on such a rent as you will nd yourself able to pay, and that because I do not desire to set you above the necessity of being indus∣trious.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Thank you, my Lord, for that, more than all the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Philip.
SP.P: Oh, my Lord!—I can∣not thank you as I ought. (He to Lucetta, takes her by the hand and says) thank God, Lucetta, I have a home for the.—Ah, my dear, help me to thank our bene∣volent landlord.
SP.STAGE: (They go towards 'Squire Aubrey, and attempt to throw themselves at his feet; he prevents them.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey,
SP.P:
(wiping her eyes.) See, sister, how malicious they are!—They want to prevent our hav∣ing a share in their pleasure!—But it remains for us, my pretty Lu∣cetta, to furnish your house, and
to give you a stock of groceries.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Nesbit.
SP.P: You are right, sister; and of that satisfaction we will not be deprived.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucetta,

P.HI: (throwing herself at La∣dy Aubrey's feet, and kissing her hand.)

SP.P: Forgive my boldness, my Lady, I can only thank you by my tears!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert,
SP.P: Oh, my God! these are thy bles∣sings, and I thank thee with sincer∣ity and truth! beseeching thee to render my benefactors as happy during life as I am at this mo∣ment!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Nesbit.
SP.P: Good old man, we are debtors to you for the kind∣ness of your prayers!—But we have interrupted your amusements; we will depart.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey
SP.P: Let us see you at the Park, to dinner, to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: Ah, Laura, I wish we could teach some of our city friends how much more ex∣quisite is the pleasure derived from an evening like this, than from being shut up in a room with wax-lights and cards, or even in the Assembly or Play-house.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Squire Aubrey.
SP.P: Farewel, my good friends, continue your mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Our blessings attend your Honours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Aubrey.
SP.P: Farewel, Lu∣cetta!
SP.STAGE: (They go out, and after a dance of the Peasants, the Scene closes.)

DIV1.HEAD: THE Mocking Bird's Nest.
A DIALOGUE.
DIV1.P: IT being the season when the Spring Vacation took place at school, which interval Mrs. Wood∣field embraced for enjoying with her little family the delights of a rural retreat. The beauty of the country daily increased; the spring was mild and forward. Her little boys William and Thomas had left school about ten days.

Their sisters and their little fe∣male kinsfolk were now employed for some hours every morning in assisting to repair the children's
linen, or making up new against their return to school, after the vacation.

The first day after their arrival, the boys amused themselves by walking through the woods, which were already in leaf. The reluct∣ant oak and the timid ash, no lon∣ger resisting the warmth of the sun, were rapidly unfolding their fresh leaves. The hedges and under∣wood were every where green and afforded concealment and shelter to an infinite number of birds, now busy in building their nests.

In the course of their walk, little Thomas, who had wandered on be∣fore, came running back out of breath, without his hat, which he held in his hand, and in which, with delight sparkling in his eyes, he showed his brother a nest of young unfledged birds.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: Oh, William! see my dear William, what a nest of birds! The boys there, that have taken them, say they are mocking-birds. Mamma, tell me if I may buy them? They ask only twenty-five cents for them. I will give half of them to William.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Mamma, are they mocking birds? May we have them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: Indeed, I am afraid they are mocking birds: and they are so tender, that you will never be able to raise them, so that to take them seems to be wanton cruelty.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P:
But mamma, these are taken already; and I am sure, if they are the tenderest little things in the world, my sister Matilda will nurse them up. Don't you remember how she nursed the young
yellow-birds, which the cat threw down from the peach tree in the garden?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: Poor, little, unfortunate creatures! see how they pant! I have no other objection to your buying them, my dear Wil∣liam, than as I think it encourages idle boys to continue their cruel robberies on the birds. But, how∣ever, as these poor mocking birds are prisoners, I believe we may rescue them out of worse hands, by taking them into ours. Can the boys there tell you where they took them from; perhaps, after they are out of sight, we may be able to put them back into the tree where they were hatched.
SP.STAGE: (The two boys go, though with some reluctance, and ask the bird-sellers to show them the place.)

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas.
SP.P: (returning to his mo∣ther.) Mamma, the boys say they got this nest out of a cherry-tree, quite in the very middle of the wood, almost a mile off; and they don't believe they can find the place for ever so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
Well, my loves, then pay for your purchase, and we will do the best we can with it. Your luckless little captives will soon be hungry, and we shall find nothing to give them here; there∣fore, I would have you Jane, with your two uncles, go home, and find a secure cage for your mocking birds, which must still, however, remain in the nest; and let your maid Rachael, assist you in feed∣ing them, as she is fond of such things, and understands something of them. Matilda, Eliza, and I, shall continue our walk, as I have
some business with a woman at the village who is spinning for me.
SP.STAGE: (The children go back to the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Eliza.
SP.P: See how carefully little Thomas steps with his treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: He will be an excellent nurse to them, and so will William, as far as their judg∣ment goes; but these unfortunate objects of childish tenderness are not unfrequently killed by kind∣ness. Neither of my little fellows have that disposition to cruelty which is said to be inherent in hu∣man nature, and which I have sometimes thought really is so, however degrading the idea may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I am sure I have thought so, very often, when I have seen how cruel some people are to animals.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
It is indeed, not
only humiliating, but it is to my feelings so distressing, that I seldom have passed through any great towns, without seeing some in∣stance of human cruelty and animal suffering that has dwelt upon my mind, and affected my spirits for the rest of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: And is it impossible to punish such horrid monsters?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
The sufferings of these miserable victims of human barbarity have not been, and there∣fore, I suppose, cannot be suffici∣ently attended to by the legislature. An hackney-coach-man may whip his galled and tired horse with im∣punity, though the exhausted ani∣mal has not strength to execute the task his brutal driver demands of him; for what positive law is there against a man's whipping his horses? or how shall his manage∣ment
of them be regulated. Were I a man, I am persuaded I should turn knight-errant in defence of the mere animal, against what are im∣properly called reasonable beings. How beautifully does the inimitable COWPER treat this subject! Speak∣ing of the domestic animal depend∣ant on man, he says,—
They prove too often at how dear a rate
He fells protection. Witness at his foot
The Spaniel dying for some venial fault,
Under dissection of the knotted scourge:
Witness the patient ox, with stripes and yells
Driven to the slaughter, goaded, as he runs,
To madness; while the savage at his heels
Laughs at the frantic sufferer's ury spent
Upon the guiltless passenger o'erthrown.
He, too, is witness, noblest of the train
That wait on man, the fleet performing horse
With unsuspecting readiness he takes
His murderer on his back; and push'd all day,
With bleeding sides, and flanks that heave for life,
To the far distant goal arrives—and dies.
Does LAW, so jealous in the cause of man,
Denounce no loom on the delinquent?—None. And alas! this is one of those evils that satire, excellent and just even as this is, can do but little to cor∣rect; for, as some periodical work, (I think the World,) in one of its essays, observes, coachmen, dray∣men, cartmen, and drovers, do not read essays; yet I have often fancied that something might be done to soften the cruel hearts of the lower classes of people, if any person of abilities would adopt re∣monstrances to their comprehension,
and teach them to fear hereafter such punishments as they now in∣flict, in dreadful retaliation.

They were by this time arrived at the village, whose few strag∣gling houses edged the extensive wood, and in a neat cottage found a decently dressed woman, whose husband was a farmer, and who was employed by Mrs. Woodfield to spin for her. She desired the woman to bring out some flax in its raw state; described the pro∣cess of making it into tow, fit for spinning, and then made each of the girls spin a thread. Not far from thence, in the same village, was a loom; they there saw it woven into sheeting and other coarse linen. Their walk home was designedly varied. Mrs. Wood∣field led them across a rustic bridge, and along the banks of a rapid stream that turned a paper-mill,
into which they entered, and saw the whole operation of making se∣veral kinds of paper. She then ex∣plained to them the materials and means by which it was made; and bade them carry their imagination back, from the stalk of the flax they had seen, bearing a blue and simple flower trembling on its slen∣der summit, through all its changes and modifications till it contributes to make a sheet of paper.

This speculation amused them for the rest of their walk. On their arrival at home, Matilda and Eliza, were agreeably surprised by a card they found upon their table, from a gentleman of their acquaint∣ance, inviting the whole family to one of Mr. Duport's much admired Fancy Balls.

Pleasure danced in the eyes of Matilda, when she found Mrs.
Woodfield intended to return an answer that they would accept this invitation. Nor was Eliza much less delighted. An immediate con∣sultation was held as to the arrange∣ment necessary; and Mrs. Wood∣field, leaving them to enjoy this antepast of pleasure, (all that life's deception frequently allow as to taste, and which is at their ages so keenly tasted,) went to inspect the little menagerie of the three young∣er children, lately increased by their mocking birds, about which they were anxiously employed. It was more necessary to repress their ill-judged solicitude, than to reprove them for carelessness of their little charge. But desirous of teaching them to reflect, she made use of the present opportunity; when the eldest of the two boys said, "Mamma, I do not believe
these little birds would be more comfortable if they were with their own mother."

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: Admitting it to be so, my dear William (though I greatly fear it is not the fact) pray tell me what you think is the opin∣ion of their own mother.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Perhaps she may be a little sorry, when she comes back and finds the nest gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: William! how do you think I should feel, if, on my return from a journey, where I had been to procure money to pay for the subsistence of my chil∣dren, I found my house vacant; and that some tyrant, whom I could not pursue or punish, had taken them from me, and condemn∣ed them to imprisonment or death? Tell me, William; and do you, Thomas, tell me, how do you think your mamma would feel?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: (looking earnestly and sorrowful) Certainly mamma, you would cry, and be very unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
Just so must the birds' mother feel, when she re∣turns and finds the vacant bough from which her nest has been torn. But, to impress this more forcibly on your memory, William, you shall learn by rote, and write these lines in your copy-book:
Oft when returning with her loaded
Th' astonished mother finds a vacant nest,
By the hard hands of unrelenting clowns
Robb'd; to the ground the vain provi∣sion falls;
Her pinions ruffle, and, low drooping, scarce
Can bear the mourner to the poplar shade.

SP.SPEAKER: Thomas
SP.P:
(with tears starting in his eyes.) Mamma, if I had thought about what the old bird must feel,
I would have made the boys I bought them of, put the nest back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
If you had done so, my dear little boy, it would hardly, in this case, have answer∣ed your humane intention; for those idle boys, as soon as you are out of sight, would have taken the nest again, and have sold the poor birds to some other person. What I mean is, not only to induce you to take care of them, since they now depend on you, but to engage you, in every case, to put yourself in the place of whatever creature you are about to injure or oppress; that you may acquire a habit of saying to yourself, How should I like to be treated thus? What should I suffer, if I were in the place of the cat we are wantonly hunting with our terriers? of the robbins which
we are wounding with our arrows? of the ducks we are setting the spaniels at? Whoever learns early in life to make these reflexions, will never have a reproach to make himself on the score of humanity, either towards the animal, or the human species.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: But, mamma, grown people hunt, and shoot, and fish, and do not seem to think there is any cruelty in it!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
So far as it be∣comes necessary to kill for our sup∣port, the animals Providence has allotted for us, there is nothing criminal in it; but to prolong their tortures is highly so, or want only to destroy any living creatures that are innoxious. For to-morrow's task, Thomas shall write out for me these lines, on the subject of inferior animals, and even reptiles and insects:
—If man's convenience, health.
Or safety interfere, his rights and claims
Are paramount, and must extinguish theirs;
Else they are all, the meanest things that are,
As free to live and to enjoy that life,
As God was free to form them at the first,
Who in his sovereign wisdom made them all▪
Ye, therefore, who love mercy, teach your sons to love it too.— And now, my dear boys, you must release your niece Jane, for she is going out to-morrow evening, and I fancy has some little preparation to make. My dear Jane, follow me.

DIV1.STAGE: SCENE, A room above stairs—MATILDA and ELIZA consulting about their Dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P:
I dare say I shall look is horribly old-fashioned as possi∣ble;
it is five months since I have seen any creature who could tell me what they wear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: (entering) "What they wear!" there is no term in the whole cant of frivolity that is half so disgusting to me as that▪ Who are they, my dear Matilda, to whose mode of dress you are de∣termined to pay such obsequious deference?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda
SP.P: (confused). Nay, ma'am, I mean people that—people that are in the world you know—that is—people—in short . . . .

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
That are not twaddles and quizzes, and grubs and goodies, and half an hundred other odd names, that you give to the folks you usually meet with in the country. Tell me now, Ma∣tilda, if it would not have afforded you great pleasure, had you known
of this ball soon enough, to have written sily to your fashionable friend, Miss Freemantle, to have sent you some very whimsical dress, with a new name, such as you ima∣gine, having never been seen in this country, would make people stare?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: I should not have ven∣tured to have done it without your leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: But, however, it would have given you pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Certainly; I should not like to appear any where but properly dressed, if I could help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: And after all, what is so proper for a young per∣son of your age, as perfect simplicity and neatness? You are still in mourning, and would not, I hope▪ have thrown it off an hour sooner on account of this public ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: But all I am afraid of is, that if one is not a little fashion∣able, one looks vulgar.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P:
It is infinitely more vulgar to appear at such an assembly over-drest. Believe me, my dear, mere dress contributes nothing to that look of elegance, or, if you will, of superiority, that you seem so jealous of. You will be convinced of this, if you should see to-morrow evening, as you probably will, a lady, named Scarfton, who is the first and finest at all our public balls; she is the wife of a man in trade of conside∣rable credit, who is often to Great Britain, as he is engaged in business there. This woman, who is ex∣tremely homely, is the greatest adept in fashions I ever saw. She runs about for a week before the commencement of the public assem∣blies,
from milliner to milliner, to see other ladies' cloaths, and then imagines something like the most remarkable, with which to induce some attention towards her. Her cloaths are made up in every vari∣ety of extravagant fashion, and each habiliment has some out-land∣ish name that she cannot even pro∣nounce. Without the least regard to proportion or propriety, she dressess out her unfortunate person in the wildest mode of the wildest girl of fashion, and the effect is, that she creates envy in the weak, and pity in the wise; and, while she thinks herself on the very pin∣nacle of politeness and elegance, I see some look upon her as a mad woman, and all consider her as bordering on insanity. Have you any ambition, Matilda, to share, with such a woman as Mrs. Scarf∣ton,
the state of public amazement?

SP.SPEAKER: Matilda.
SP.P: Dear ma'am, can you suppose I have?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Woodfield.
SP.P: Let us hear no more, then of wishes to know what they ear. My mantua-ma∣ker, who makes cloaths for such as are esteemed fashionable, often forces me to smile, by advising me to have my gown made so and so, assuring me they wear them so: and when I ask who she simper∣ingly informs me, that Miss Kty Doeskin, daughter of Mr. Doe∣skin, an eminent leather dresser, and Miss Clutterbucks, daughter of Mr. Clutterbucks, green-grocer and dealer, have had new dresses from London, "quite in taste," which they have given me leave to look at.

DIV1.P:
Such are the histories of fashions. The belles, who derive their in∣formation
from the Miss Doeskins and the Miss Clutterbucks, will take the lead in elegance, till Mrs. Scarfton's husband arrives next from London, then the ton of articles a la Doesins and Clutterbucks, will be entirely superseded by the know∣ledge acquired by the happier few, who, are admitted contem∣plae the superior elegance of the lady's of that house.

Do you think, Matilda, such hemeron triumphs as these, are worth a moment's thought? I am far, however, from wishing you entirely to decline appearing in what is called in the fashion; such affection would be as ridiculous on one hand, as running into its wildest excesses is on the other. A young woman should dress as the persons of her age dress, but with∣out sacrificing decency, common
sense, or proportion. Nothing, perhaps, is a more glaring absur∣dity, among all the weaknesses women are charged with, than the undistinguishing avidity with which women of all ranks, ages and fi∣gures, run into modes of dss that neither suits the person or pockets of all, and probably disfigures five out of six. Some slender girl of fashion imagines, in the caprice of imputed perfections, manner of dressing which shall show every ne of those perfections. It succeeds; the men compliment, the Misses envy, and the mob wonder. In a few days, the fat red-faced matron of fifty; the dwarfish Miss, who has owed her little consequence to her heels and her head; the round snug damsel, as thick as she is long; and the genteel young lady, that has lived on vinegar till she is reduced
to a study for an anatomist: all follow the fashion: but hardly are they established in it, before some other, more preposterous succeeds; and the former,
Like the baseless fabric of a vision,
Leaves not a wreck behind; unless it be in that description of persons who, in Shakespeare's time were called,
The velvet guards, and Sunday citizens.

I have often thought, that if were possible to have a set of dolls dressed in the fashions of the last two hundred years, it would be an amusing spectacle, and not without its use, as a lesson to human vanity. The modes are now forgotten, and the names of the triflers who in∣vented them are forgotten too; the only memorial that remains of ei∣ther exists, perhaps, in some book,
where they are accidentally alluded to, and which the commentary of the antiquarian and the critic may have explained.

It should be a lesson to the span∣gled butterfly of the passing day, and it should teach her the superi∣ority of Intellect over Beauty, when she reflects, that the charms of so many lovely women live now only in the memory of mankind by the poets who have celebrated their names. Even the beautiful Lady Coventry is obliged to Mason for telling us what she was. "The liquid lustre of her eyes," is thought of but faintly by those who read of the incomparably fascinating charms that graced her person. There is a snnet of Drayton's ad∣dressed to a lady, whose merit he glories in being able to rescue from , which is apposite to this
topic. It is not so polished as mo∣dern poetry; but is highly ex∣pressive of his opinion of the power of poesy, and of those objects of transient admiration, of whom it has been said, THEY had no POET and THEY died.

LG.L: How many foolish, paltry, painted things,
That now in coaches trouble every street,
Shall be forgotten—whom no poet sings
E'er they are well wrapped in their winding sheet;
But to t eternity shall give,
When nothing else remaineth of those days,
And queens hereafter shall be glad to live
Upon the alms of my superuous praise.
Virgins and matrons, reading thus my rhymes.
Shall be so much delighted with .
That they shall grieve they lived not in these times,
To have seen thee, their sexes greatest glory.
For thou shalt soar above the vulgar throng,
And still survive in my immortal Song▪
